62def rot90(m, k=1, axes=(0,1)): 

63 """ 

64 Rotate an array by 90 degrees in the plane specified by axes. 

65 

66 Rotation direction is from the first towards the second axis. 

67 

68 Parameters 

69 ---------- 

70 m : array_like 

71 Array of two or more dimensions. 

72 k : integer 

73 Number of times the array is rotated by 90 degrees. 

74 axes: (2,) array_like 

75 The array is rotated in the plane defined by the axes. 

76 Axes must be different. 

77 

78 .. versionadded:: 1.12.0 

79 

80 Returns 

81 ------- 

82 y : ndarray 

83 A rotated view of `m`. 

84 

85 See Also 

86 -------- 

87 flip : Reverse the order of elements in an array along the given axis. 

88 fliplr : Flip an array horizontally. 

89 flipud : Flip an array vertically. 

90 

91 Notes 

92 ----- 

93 rot90(m, k=1, axes=(1,0)) is the reverse of rot90(m, k=1, axes=(0,1)) 

94 rot90(m, k=1, axes=(1,0)) is equivalent to rot90(m, k=-1, axes=(0,1)) 

95 

96 Examples 

97 -------- 

98 >>> m = np.array([[1,2],[3,4]], int) 

99 >>> m 

100 array([[1, 2], 

101 [3, 4]]) 

102 >>> np.rot90(m) 

103 array([[2, 4], 

104 [1, 3]]) 

105 >>> np.rot90(m, 2) 

106 array([[4, 3], 

107 [2, 1]]) 

108 >>> m = np.arange(8).reshape((2,2,2)) 

109 >>> np.rot90(m, 1, (1,2)) 

110 array([[[1, 3], 

111 [0, 2]], 

112 [[5, 7], 

113 [4, 6]]]) 

114 

115 """ 

116 axes = tuple(axes) 

117 if len(axes) != 2: 

118 raise ValueError("len(axes) must be 2.") 

119 

120 m = asanyarray(m) 

121 

122 if axes[0] == axes[1] or absolute(axes[0] - axes[1]) == m.ndim: 

123 raise ValueError("Axes must be different.") 

124 

125 if (axes[0] >= m.ndim or axes[0] < -m.ndim 

126 or axes[1] >= m.ndim or axes[1] < -m.ndim): 

127 raise ValueError("Axes={} out of range for array of ndim={}." 

128 .format(axes, m.ndim)) 

129 

130 k %= 4 

131 

132 if k == 0: 

133 return m[:] 

134 if k == 2: 

135 return flip(flip(m, axes[0]), axes[1]) 

136 

137 axes_list = arange(0, m.ndim) 

138 (axes_list[axes[0]], axes_list[axes[1]]) = (axes_list[axes[1]], 

139 axes_list[axes[0]]) 

140 

141 if k == 1: 

142 return transpose(flip(m,axes[1]), axes_list) 

143 else: 

144 # k == 3 

145 return flip(transpose(m, axes_list), axes[1]) 

146

148def flip(m, axis=None): 

149 """ 

150 Reverse the order of elements in an array along the given axis. 

151 

152 The shape of the array is preserved, but the elements are reordered. 

153 

154 .. versionadded:: 1.12.0 

155 

156 Parameters 

157 ---------- 

158 m : array_like 

159 Input array. 

160 axis : None or int or tuple of ints, optional 

161 Axis or axes along which to flip over. The default, 

162 axis=None, will flip over all of the axes of the input array. 

163 If axis is negative it counts from the last to the first axis. 

164 

165 If axis is a tuple of ints, flipping is performed on all of the axes 

166 specified in the tuple. 

167 

168 .. versionchanged:: 1.15.0 

169 None and tuples of axes are supported 

170 

171 Returns 

172 ------- 

173 out : array_like 

174 A view of `m` with the entries of axis reversed. Since a view is 

175 returned, this operation is done in constant time. 

176 

177 See Also 

178 -------- 

179 flipud : Flip an array vertically (axis=0). 

180 fliplr : Flip an array horizontally (axis=1). 

181 

182 Notes 

183 ----- 

184 flip(m, 0) is equivalent to flipud(m). 

185 

186 flip(m, 1) is equivalent to fliplr(m). 

187 

188 flip(m, n) corresponds to ``m[...,::-1,...]`` with ``::-1`` at position n. 

189 

190 flip(m) corresponds to ``m[::-1,::-1,...,::-1]`` with ``::-1`` at all 

191 positions. 

192 

193 flip(m, (0, 1)) corresponds to ``m[::-1,::-1,...]`` with ``::-1`` at 

194 position 0 and position 1. 

195 

196 Examples 

197 -------- 

198 >>> A = np.arange(8).reshape((2,2,2)) 

199 >>> A 

200 array([[[0, 1], 

201 [2, 3]], 

202 [[4, 5], 

203 [6, 7]]]) 

204 >>> flip(A, 0) 

205 array([[[4, 5], 

206 [6, 7]], 

207 [[0, 1], 

208 [2, 3]]]) 

209 >>> flip(A, 1) 

210 array([[[2, 3], 

211 [0, 1]], 

212 [[6, 7], 

213 [4, 5]]]) 

214 >>> np.flip(A) 

215 array([[[7, 6], 

216 [5, 4]], 

217 [[3, 2], 

218 [1, 0]]]) 

219 >>> np.flip(A, (0, 2)) 

220 array([[[5, 4], 

221 [7, 6]], 

222 [[1, 0], 

223 [3, 2]]]) 

224 >>> A = np.random.randn(3,4,5) 

225 >>> np.all(flip(A,2) == A[:,:,::-1,...]) 

226 True 

227 """ 

228 if not hasattr(m, 'ndim'): 

229 m = asarray(m) 

230 if axis is None: 

231 indexer = (np.s_[::-1],) * m.ndim 

232 else: 

233 axis = _nx.normalize_axis_tuple(axis, m.ndim) 

234 indexer = [np.s_[:]] * m.ndim 

235 for ax in axis: 

236 indexer[ax] = np.s_[::-1] 

237 indexer = tuple(indexer) 

238 return m[indexer]

241def iterable(y): 

242 """ 

243 Check whether or not an object can be iterated over. 

244 

245 Parameters 

246 ---------- 

247 y : object 

248 Input object. 

249 

250 Returns 

251 ------- 

252 b : bool 

253 Return ``True`` if the object has an iterator method or is a 

254 sequence and ``False`` otherwise. 

255 

256 

257 Examples 

258 -------- 

259 >>> np.iterable([1, 2, 3]) 

260 True 

261 >>> np.iterable(2) 

262 False 

263 

264 """ 

265 try: 

266 iter(y) 

267 except TypeError: 

268 return False 

269 return True

272def average(a, axis=None, weights=None, returned=False): 

273 """ 

274 Compute the weighted average along the specified axis. 

275 

276 Parameters 

277 ---------- 

278 a : array_like 

279 Array containing data to be averaged. If `a` is not an array, a 

280 conversion is attempted. 

281 axis : None or int or tuple of ints, optional 

282 Axis or axes along which to average `a`. The default, 

283 axis=None, will average over all of the elements of the input array. 

284 If axis is negative it counts from the last to the first axis. 

285 

286 .. versionadded:: 1.7.0 

287 

288 If axis is a tuple of ints, averaging is performed on all of the axes 

289 specified in the tuple instead of a single axis or all the axes as 

290 before. 

291 weights : array_like, optional 

292 An array of weights associated with the values in `a`. Each value in 

293 `a` contributes to the average according to its associated weight. 

294 The weights array can either be 1-D (in which case its length must be 

295 the size of `a` along the given axis) or of the same shape as `a`. 

296 If `weights=None`, then all data in `a` are assumed to have a 

297 weight equal to one. 

298 returned : bool, optional 

299 Default is `False`. If `True`, the tuple (`average`, `sum_of_weights`) 

300 is returned, otherwise only the average is returned. 

301 If `weights=None`, `sum_of_weights` is equivalent to the number of 

302 elements over which the average is taken. 

303 

304 

305 Returns 

306 ------- 

307 average, [sum_of_weights] : array_type or double 

308 Return the average along the specified axis. When returned is `True`, 

309 return a tuple with the average as the first element and the sum 

310 of the weights as the second element. The return type is `Float` 

311 if `a` is of integer type, otherwise it is of the same type as `a`. 

312 `sum_of_weights` is of the same type as `average`. 

313 

314 Raises 

315 ------ 

316 ZeroDivisionError 

317 When all weights along axis are zero. See `numpy.ma.average` for a 

318 version robust to this type of error. 

319 TypeError 

320 When the length of 1D `weights` is not the same as the shape of `a` 

321 along axis. 

322 

323 See Also 

324 -------- 

325 mean 

326 

327 ma.average : average for masked arrays -- useful if your data contains 

328 "missing" values 

329 

330 Examples 

331 -------- 

332 >>> data = range(1,5) 

333 >>> data 

334 [1, 2, 3, 4] 

335 >>> np.average(data) 

336 2.5 

337 >>> np.average(range(1,11), weights=range(10,0,-1)) 

338 4.0 

339 

340 >>> data = np.arange(6).reshape((3,2)) 

341 >>> data 

342 array([[0, 1], 

343 [2, 3], 

344 [4, 5]]) 

345 >>> np.average(data, axis=1, weights=[1./4, 3./4]) 

346 array([ 0.75, 2.75, 4.75]) 

347 >>> np.average(data, weights=[1./4, 3./4]) 

348 Traceback (most recent call last): 

349 ... 

350 TypeError: Axis must be specified when shapes of a and weights differ. 

351 

352 """ 

353 a = np.asanyarray(a) 

354 

355 if weights is None: 

356 avg = a.mean(axis) 

357 scl = avg.dtype.type(a.size/avg.size) 

358 else: 

359 wgt = np.asanyarray(weights) 

360 

361 if issubclass(a.dtype.type, (np.integer, np.bool_)): 

362 result_dtype = np.result_type(a.dtype, wgt.dtype, 'f8') 

363 else: 

364 result_dtype = np.result_type(a.dtype, wgt.dtype) 

365 

366 # Sanity checks 

367 if a.shape != wgt.shape: 

368 if axis is None: 

369 raise TypeError( 

370 "Axis must be specified when shapes of a and weights " 

371 "differ.") 

372 if wgt.ndim != 1: 

373 raise TypeError( 

374 "1D weights expected when shapes of a and weights differ.") 

375 if wgt.shape[0] != a.shape[axis]: 

376 raise ValueError( 

377 "Length of weights not compatible with specified axis.") 

378 

379 # setup wgt to broadcast along axis 

380 wgt = np.broadcast_to(wgt, (a.ndim-1)*(1,) + wgt.shape) 

381 wgt = wgt.swapaxes(-1, axis) 

382 

383 scl = wgt.sum(axis=axis, dtype=result_dtype) 

384 if np.any(scl == 0.0): 

385 raise ZeroDivisionError( 

386 "Weights sum to zero, can't be normalized") 

387 

388 avg = np.multiply(a, wgt, dtype=result_dtype).sum(axis)/scl 

389 

390 if returned: 

391 if scl.shape != avg.shape: 

392 scl = np.broadcast_to(scl, avg.shape).copy() 

393 return avg, scl 

394 else: 

395 return avg

398def asarray_chkfinite(a, dtype=None, order=None): 

399 """Convert the input to an array, checking for NaNs or Infs. 

400 

401 Parameters 

402 ---------- 

403 a : array_like 

404 Input data, in any form that can be converted to an array. This 

405 includes lists, lists of tuples, tuples, tuples of tuples, tuples 

406 of lists and ndarrays. Success requires no NaNs or Infs. 

407 dtype : data-type, optional 

408 By default, the data-type is inferred from the input data. 

409 order : {'C', 'F'}, optional 

410 Whether to use row-major (C-style) or 

411 column-major (Fortran-style) memory representation. 

412 Defaults to 'C'. 

413 

414 Returns 

415 ------- 

416 out : ndarray 

417 Array interpretation of `a`. No copy is performed if the input 

418 is already an ndarray. If `a` is a subclass of ndarray, a base 

419 class ndarray is returned. 

420 

421 Raises 

422 ------ 

423 ValueError 

424 Raises ValueError if `a` contains NaN (Not a Number) or Inf (Infinity). 

425 

426 See Also 

427 -------- 

428 asarray : Create and array. 

429 asanyarray : Similar function which passes through subclasses. 

430 ascontiguousarray : Convert input to a contiguous array. 

431 asfarray : Convert input to a floating point ndarray. 

432 asfortranarray : Convert input to an ndarray with column-major 

433 memory order. 

434 fromiter : Create an array from an iterator. 

435 fromfunction : Construct an array by executing a function on grid 

436 positions. 

437 

438 Examples 

439 -------- 

440 Convert a list into an array. If all elements are finite 

441 ``asarray_chkfinite`` is identical to ``asarray``. 

442 

443 >>> a = [1, 2] 

444 >>> np.asarray_chkfinite(a, dtype=float) 

445 array([1., 2.]) 

446 

447 Raises ValueError if array_like contains Nans or Infs. 

448 

449 >>> a = [1, 2, np.inf] 

450 >>> try: 

451 ... np.asarray_chkfinite(a) 

452 ... except ValueError: 

453 ... print('ValueError') 

454 ... 

455 ValueError 

456 

457 """ 

458 a = asarray(a, dtype=dtype, order=order) 

459 if a.dtype.char in typecodes['AllFloat'] and not np.isfinite(a).all(): 

460 raise ValueError( 

461 "array must not contain infs or NaNs") 

462 return a

465def piecewise(x, condlist, funclist, *args, **kw): 

466 """ 

467 Evaluate a piecewise-defined function. 

468 

469 Given a set of conditions and corresponding functions, evaluate each 

470 function on the input data wherever its condition is true. 

471 

472 Parameters 

473 ---------- 

474 x : ndarray or scalar 

475 The input domain. 

476 condlist : list of bool arrays or bool scalars 

477 Each boolean array corresponds to a function in `funclist`. Wherever 

478 `condlist[i]` is True, `funclist[i](x)` is used as the output value. 

479 

480 Each boolean array in `condlist` selects a piece of `x`, 

481 and should therefore be of the same shape as `x`. 

482 

483 The length of `condlist` must correspond to that of `funclist`. 

484 If one extra function is given, i.e. if 

485 ``len(funclist) == len(condlist) + 1``, then that extra function 

486 is the default value, used wherever all conditions are false. 

487 funclist : list of callables, f(x,*args,**kw), or scalars 

488 Each function is evaluated over `x` wherever its corresponding 

489 condition is True. It should take a 1d array as input and give an 1d 

490 array or a scalar value as output. If, instead of a callable, 

491 a scalar is provided then a constant function (``lambda x: scalar``) is 

492 assumed. 

493 args : tuple, optional 

494 Any further arguments given to `piecewise` are passed to the functions 

495 upon execution, i.e., if called ``piecewise(..., ..., 1, 'a')``, then 

496 each function is called as ``f(x, 1, 'a')``. 

497 kw : dict, optional 

498 Keyword arguments used in calling `piecewise` are passed to the 

499 functions upon execution, i.e., if called 

500 ``piecewise(..., ..., alpha=1)``, then each function is called as 

501 ``f(x, alpha=1)``. 

502 

503 Returns 

504 ------- 

505 out : ndarray 

506 The output is the same shape and type as x and is found by 

507 calling the functions in `funclist` on the appropriate portions of `x`, 

508 as defined by the boolean arrays in `condlist`. Portions not covered 

509 by any condition have a default value of 0. 

510 

511 

512 See Also 

513 -------- 

514 choose, select, where 

515 

516 Notes 

517 ----- 

518 This is similar to choose or select, except that functions are 

519 evaluated on elements of `x` that satisfy the corresponding condition from 

520 `condlist`. 

521 

522 The result is:: 

523 

524 |-- 

525 |funclist[0](x[condlist[0]]) 

526 out = |funclist[1](x[condlist[1]]) 

527 |... 

528 |funclist[n2](x[condlist[n2]]) 

529 |-- 

530 

531 Examples 

532 -------- 

533 Define the sigma function, which is -1 for ``x < 0`` and +1 for ``x >= 0``. 

534 

535 >>> x = np.linspace(-2.5, 2.5, 6) 

536 >>> np.piecewise(x, [x < 0, x >= 0], [-1, 1]) 

537 array([-1., -1., -1., 1., 1., 1.]) 

538 

539 Define the absolute value, which is ``-x`` for ``x <0`` and ``x`` for 

540 ``x >= 0``. 

541 

542 >>> np.piecewise(x, [x < 0, x >= 0], [lambda x: -x, lambda x: x]) 

543 array([ 2.5, 1.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1.5, 2.5]) 

544 

545 Apply the same function to a scalar value. 

546 

547 >>> y = -2 

548 >>> np.piecewise(y, [y < 0, y >= 0], [lambda x: -x, lambda x: x]) 

549 array(2) 

550 

551 """ 

552 x = asanyarray(x) 

553 n2 = len(funclist) 

554 

555 # undocumented: single condition is promoted to a list of one condition 

556 if isscalar(condlist) or ( 

557 not isinstance(condlist[0], (list, ndarray)) and x.ndim != 0): 

558 condlist = [condlist] 

559 

560 condlist = array(condlist, dtype=bool) 

561 n = len(condlist) 

562 

563 if n == n2 - 1: # compute the "otherwise" condition. 

564 condelse = ~np.any(condlist, axis=0, keepdims=True) 

565 condlist = np.concatenate([condlist, condelse], axis=0) 

566 n += 1 

567 elif n != n2: 

568 raise ValueError( 

569 "with {} condition(s), either {} or {} functions are expected" 

570 .format(n, n, n+1) 

571 ) 

572 

573 y = zeros(x.shape, x.dtype) 

574 for k in range(n): 

575 item = funclist[k] 

576 if not isinstance(item, collections_abc.Callable): 

577 y[condlist[k]] = item 

578 else: 

579 vals = x[condlist[k]] 

580 if vals.size > 0: 

581 y[condlist[k]] = item(vals, *args, **kw) 

582 

583 return y

586def select(condlist, choicelist, default=0): 

587 """ 

588 Return an array drawn from elements in choicelist, depending on conditions. 

589 

590 Parameters 

591 ---------- 

592 condlist : list of bool ndarrays 

593 The list of conditions which determine from which array in `choicelist` 

594 the output elements are taken. When multiple conditions are satisfied, 

595 the first one encountered in `condlist` is used. 

596 choicelist : list of ndarrays 

597 The list of arrays from which the output elements are taken. It has 

598 to be of the same length as `condlist`. 

599 default : scalar, optional 

600 The element inserted in `output` when all conditions evaluate to False. 

601 

602 Returns 

603 ------- 

604 output : ndarray 

605 The output at position m is the m-th element of the array in 

606 `choicelist` where the m-th element of the corresponding array in 

607 `condlist` is True. 

608 

609 See Also 

610 -------- 

611 where : Return elements from one of two arrays depending on condition. 

612 take, choose, compress, diag, diagonal 

613 

614 Examples 

615 -------- 

616 >>> x = np.arange(10) 

617 >>> condlist = [x<3, x>5] 

618 >>> choicelist = [x, x**2] 

619 >>> np.select(condlist, choicelist) 

620 array([ 0, 1, 2, 0, 0, 0, 36, 49, 64, 81]) 

621 

622 """ 

623 # Check the size of condlist and choicelist are the same, or abort. 

624 if len(condlist) != len(choicelist): 

625 raise ValueError( 

626 'list of cases must be same length as list of conditions') 

627 

628 # Now that the dtype is known, handle the deprecated select([], []) case 

629 if len(condlist) == 0: 

630 # 2014-02-24, 1.9 

631 warnings.warn("select with an empty condition list is not possible" 

632 "and will be deprecated", 

633 DeprecationWarning, stacklevel=2) 

634 return np.asarray(default)[()] 

635 

636 choicelist = [np.asarray(choice) for choice in choicelist] 

637 choicelist.append(np.asarray(default)) 

638 

639 # need to get the result type before broadcasting for correct scalar 

640 # behaviour 

641 dtype = np.result_type(*choicelist) 

642 

643 # Convert conditions to arrays and broadcast conditions and choices 

644 # as the shape is needed for the result. Doing it separately optimizes 

645 # for example when all choices are scalars. 

646 condlist = np.broadcast_arrays(*condlist) 

647 choicelist = np.broadcast_arrays(*choicelist) 

648 

649 # If cond array is not an ndarray in boolean format or scalar bool, abort. 

650 deprecated_ints = False 

651 for i in range(len(condlist)): 

652 cond = condlist[i] 

653 if cond.dtype.type is not np.bool_: 

654 if np.issubdtype(cond.dtype, np.integer): 

655 # A previous implementation accepted int ndarrays accidentally. 

656 # Supported here deliberately, but deprecated. 

657 condlist[i] = condlist[i].astype(bool) 

658 deprecated_ints = True 

659 else: 

660 raise ValueError( 

661 'invalid entry {} in condlist: should be boolean ndarray'.format(i)) 

662 

663 if deprecated_ints: 

664 # 2014-02-24, 1.9 

665 msg = "select condlists containing integer ndarrays is deprecated " \ 

666 "and will be removed in the future. Use `.astype(bool)` to " \ 

667 "convert to bools." 

668 warnings.warn(msg, DeprecationWarning, stacklevel=2) 

669 

670 if choicelist[0].ndim == 0: 

671 # This may be common, so avoid the call. 

672 result_shape = condlist[0].shape 

673 else: 

674 result_shape = np.broadcast_arrays(condlist[0], choicelist[0])[0].shape 

675 

676 result = np.full(result_shape, choicelist[-1], dtype) 

677 

678 # Use np.copyto to burn each choicelist array onto result, using the 

679 # corresponding condlist as a boolean mask. This is done in reverse 

680 # order since the first choice should take precedence. 

681 choicelist = choicelist[-2::-1] 

682 condlist = condlist[::-1] 

683 for choice, cond in zip(choicelist, condlist): 

684 np.copyto(result, choice, where=cond) 

685 

686 return result 

687 

688 

689def copy(a, order='K'): 

690 """ 

691 Return an array copy of the given object. 

692 

693 Parameters 

694 ---------- 

695 a : array_like 

696 Input data. 

697 order : {'C', 'F', 'A', 'K'}, optional 

698 Controls the memory layout of the copy. 'C' means C-order, 

699 'F' means F-order, 'A' means 'F' if `a` is Fortran contiguous, 

700 'C' otherwise. 'K' means match the layout of `a` as closely 

701 as possible. (Note that this function and :meth:`ndarray.copy` are very 

702 similar, but have different default values for their order= 

703 arguments.) 

704 

705 Returns 

706 ------- 

707 arr : ndarray 

708 Array interpretation of `a`. 

709 

710 Notes 

711 ----- 

712 This is equivalent to: 

713 

714 >>> np.array(a, copy=True) #doctest: +SKIP 

715 

716 Examples 

717 -------- 

718 Create an array x, with a reference y and a copy z: 

719 

720 >>> x = np.array([1, 2, 3]) 

721 >>> y = x 

722 >>> z = np.copy(x) 

723 

724 Note that, when we modify x, y changes, but not z: 

725 

726 >>> x[0] = 10 

727 >>> x[0] == y[0] 

728 True 

729 >>> x[0] == z[0] 

730 False 

731 

732 """ 

733 return array(a, order=order, copy=True) 

734 

735# Basic operations 

736 

737 

738def gradient(f, *varargs, **kwargs): 

739 """ 

740 Return the gradient of an N-dimensional array. 

741 

742 The gradient is computed using second order accurate central differences 

743 in the interior points and either first or second order accurate one-sides 

744 (forward or backwards) differences at the boundaries. 

745 The returned gradient hence has the same shape as the input array. 

746 

747 Parameters 

748 ---------- 

749 f : array_like 

750 An N-dimensional array containing samples of a scalar function. 

751 varargs : list of scalar or array, optional 

752 Spacing between f values. Default unitary spacing for all dimensions. 

753 Spacing can be specified using: 

754 

755 1. single scalar to specify a sample distance for all dimensions. 

756 2. N scalars to specify a constant sample distance for each dimension. 

757 i.e. `dx`, `dy`, `dz`, ... 

758 3. N arrays to specify the coordinates of the values along each 

759 dimension of F. The length of the array must match the size of 

760 the corresponding dimension 

761 4. Any combination of N scalars/arrays with the meaning of 2. and 3. 

762 

763 If `axis` is given, the number of varargs must equal the number of axes. 

764 Default: 1. 

765 

766 edge_order : {1, 2}, optional 

767 Gradient is calculated using N-th order accurate differences 

768 at the boundaries. Default: 1. 

769 

770 .. versionadded:: 1.9.1 

771 

772 axis : None or int or tuple of ints, optional 

773 Gradient is calculated only along the given axis or axes 

774 The default (axis = None) is to calculate the gradient for all the axes 

775 of the input array. axis may be negative, in which case it counts from 

776 the last to the first axis. 

777 

778 .. versionadded:: 1.11.0 

779 

780 Returns 

781 ------- 

782 gradient : ndarray or list of ndarray 

783 A set of ndarrays (or a single ndarray if there is only one dimension) 

784 corresponding to the derivatives of f with respect to each dimension. 

785 Each derivative has the same shape as f. 

786 

787 Examples 

788 -------- 

789 >>> f = np.array([1, 2, 4, 7, 11, 16], dtype=float) 

790 >>> np.gradient(f) 

791 array([ 1. , 1.5, 2.5, 3.5, 4.5, 5. ]) 

792 >>> np.gradient(f, 2) 

793 array([ 0.5 , 0.75, 1.25, 1.75, 2.25, 2.5 ]) 

794 

795 Spacing can be also specified with an array that represents the coordinates 

796 of the values F along the dimensions. 

797 For instance a uniform spacing: 

798 

799 >>> x = np.arange(f.size) 

800 >>> np.gradient(f, x) 

801 array([ 1. , 1.5, 2.5, 3.5, 4.5, 5. ]) 

802 

803 Or a non uniform one: 

804 

805 >>> x = np.array([0., 1., 1.5, 3.5, 4., 6.], dtype=float) 

806 >>> np.gradient(f, x) 

807 array([ 1. , 3. , 3.5, 6.7, 6.9, 2.5]) 

808 

809 For two dimensional arrays, the return will be two arrays ordered by 

810 axis. In this example the first array stands for the gradient in 

811 rows and the second one in columns direction: 

812 

813 >>> np.gradient(np.array([[1, 2, 6], [3, 4, 5]], dtype=float)) 

814 [array([[ 2., 2., -1.], 

815 [ 2., 2., -1.]]), array([[ 1. , 2.5, 4. ], 

816 [ 1. , 1. , 1. ]])] 

817 

818 In this example the spacing is also specified: 

819 uniform for axis=0 and non uniform for axis=1 

820 

821 >>> dx = 2. 

822 >>> y = [1., 1.5, 3.5] 

823 >>> np.gradient(np.array([[1, 2, 6], [3, 4, 5]], dtype=float), dx, y) 

824 [array([[ 1. , 1. , -0.5], 

825 [ 1. , 1. , -0.5]]), array([[ 2. , 2. , 2. ], 

826 [ 2. , 1.7, 0.5]])] 

827 

828 It is possible to specify how boundaries are treated using `edge_order` 

829 

830 >>> x = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4]) 

831 >>> f = x**2 

832 >>> np.gradient(f, edge_order=1) 

833 array([ 1., 2., 4., 6., 7.]) 

834 >>> np.gradient(f, edge_order=2) 

835 array([-0., 2., 4., 6., 8.]) 

836 

837 The `axis` keyword can be used to specify a subset of axes of which the 

838 gradient is calculated 

839 

840 >>> np.gradient(np.array([[1, 2, 6], [3, 4, 5]], dtype=float), axis=0) 

841 array([[ 2., 2., -1.], 

842 [ 2., 2., -1.]]) 

843 

844 Notes 

845 ----- 

846 Assuming that :math:`f\\in C^{3}` (i.e., :math:`f` has at least 3 continuous 

847 derivatives) and let :math:`h_{*}` be a non-homogeneous stepsize, we 

848 minimize the "consistency error" :math:`\\eta_{i}` between the true gradient 

849 and its estimate from a linear combination of the neighboring grid-points: 

850 

851 .. math:: 

852 

853 \\eta_{i} = f_{i}^{\\left(1\\right)} - 

854 \\left[ \\alpha f\\left(x_{i}\\right) + 

855 \\beta f\\left(x_{i} + h_{d}\\right) + 

856 \\gamma f\\left(x_{i}-h_{s}\\right) 

857 \\right] 

858 

859 By substituting :math:`f(x_{i} + h_{d})` and :math:`f(x_{i} - h_{s})` 

860 with their Taylor series expansion, this translates into solving 

861 the following the linear system: 

862 

863 .. math:: 

864 

865 \\left\\{ 

866 \\begin{array}{r} 

867 \\alpha+\\beta+\\gamma=0 \\\\ 

868 \\beta h_{d}-\\gamma h_{s}=1 \\\\ 

869 \\beta h_{d}^{2}+\\gamma h_{s}^{2}=0 

870 \\end{array} 

871 \\right. 

872 

873 The resulting approximation of :math:`f_{i}^{(1)}` is the following: 

874 

875 .. math:: 

876 

877 \\hat f_{i}^{(1)} = 

878 \\frac{ 

879 h_{s}^{2}f\\left(x_{i} + h_{d}\\right) 

880 + \\left(h_{d}^{2} - h_{s}^{2}\\right)f\\left(x_{i}\\right) 

881 - h_{d}^{2}f\\left(x_{i}-h_{s}\\right)} 

882 { h_{s}h_{d}\\left(h_{d} + h_{s}\\right)} 

883 + \\mathcal{O}\\left(\\frac{h_{d}h_{s}^{2} 

884 + h_{s}h_{d}^{2}}{h_{d} 

885 + h_{s}}\\right) 

886 

887 It is worth noting that if :math:`h_{s}=h_{d}` 

888 (i.e., data are evenly spaced) 

889 we find the standard second order approximation: 

890 

891 .. math:: 

892 

893 \\hat f_{i}^{(1)}= 

894 \\frac{f\\left(x_{i+1}\\right) - f\\left(x_{i-1}\\right)}{2h} 

895 + \\mathcal{O}\\left(h^{2}\\right) 

896 

897 With a similar procedure the forward/backward approximations used for 

898 boundaries can be derived. 

899 

900 References 

901 ---------- 

902 .. [1] Quarteroni A., Sacco R., Saleri F. (2007) Numerical Mathematics 

903 (Texts in Applied Mathematics). New York: Springer. 

904 .. [2] Durran D. R. (1999) Numerical Methods for Wave Equations 

905 in Geophysical Fluid Dynamics. New York: Springer. 

906 .. [3] Fornberg B. (1988) Generation of Finite Difference Formulas on 

907 Arbitrarily Spaced Grids, 

908 Mathematics of Computation 51, no. 184 : 699-706. 

909 `PDF <http://www.ams.org/journals/mcom/1988-51-184/ 

910 S0025-5718-1988-0935077-0/S0025-5718-1988-0935077-0.pdf>`_. 

911 """ 

912 f = np.asanyarray(f) 

913 N = f.ndim # number of dimensions 

914 

915 axes = kwargs.pop('axis', None) 

916 if axes is None: 

917 axes = tuple(range(N)) 

918 else: 

919 axes = _nx.normalize_axis_tuple(axes, N) 

920 

921 len_axes = len(axes) 

922 n = len(varargs) 

923 if n == 0: 

924 # no spacing argument - use 1 in all axes 

925 dx = [1.0] * len_axes 

926 elif n == 1 and np.ndim(varargs[0]) == 0: 

927 # single scalar for all axes 

928 dx = varargs * len_axes 

929 elif n == len_axes: 

930 # scalar or 1d array for each axis 

931 dx = list(varargs) 

932 for i, distances in enumerate(dx): 

933 if np.ndim(distances) == 0: 

934 continue 

935 elif np.ndim(distances) != 1: 

936 raise ValueError("distances must be either scalars or 1d") 

937 if len(distances) != f.shape[axes[i]]: 

938 raise ValueError("when 1d, distances must match " 

939 "the length of the corresponding dimension") 

940 diffx = np.diff(distances) 

941 # if distances are constant reduce to the scalar case 

942 # since it brings a consistent speedup 

943 if (diffx == diffx[0]).all(): 

944 diffx = diffx[0] 

945 dx[i] = diffx 

946 else: 

947 raise TypeError("invalid number of arguments") 

948 

949 edge_order = kwargs.pop('edge_order', 1) 

950 if kwargs: 

951 raise TypeError('"{}" are not valid keyword arguments.'.format( 

952 '", "'.join(kwargs.keys()))) 

953 if edge_order > 2: 

954 raise ValueError("'edge_order' greater than 2 not supported") 

955 

956 # use central differences on interior and one-sided differences on the 

957 # endpoints. This preserves second order-accuracy over the full domain. 

958 

959 outvals = [] 

960 

961 # create slice objects --- initially all are [:, :, ..., :] 

962 slice1 = [slice(None)]*N 

963 slice2 = [slice(None)]*N 

964 slice3 = [slice(None)]*N 

965 slice4 = [slice(None)]*N 

966 

967 otype = f.dtype 

968 if otype.type is np.datetime64: 

969 # the timedelta dtype with the same unit information 

970 otype = np.dtype(otype.name.replace('datetime', 'timedelta')) 

971 # view as timedelta to allow addition 

972 f = f.view(otype) 

973 elif otype.type is np.timedelta64: 

974 pass 

975 elif np.issubdtype(otype, np.inexact): 

976 pass 

977 else: 

978 # all other types convert to floating point 

979 otype = np.double 

980 

981 for axis, ax_dx in zip(axes, dx): 

982 if f.shape[axis] < edge_order + 1: 

983 raise ValueError( 

984 "Shape of array too small to calculate a numerical gradient, " 

985 "at least (edge_order + 1) elements are required.") 

986 # result allocation 

987 out = np.empty_like(f, dtype=otype) 

988 

989 # spacing for the current axis 

990 uniform_spacing = np.ndim(ax_dx) == 0 

991 

992 # Numerical differentiation: 2nd order interior 

993 slice1[axis] = slice(1, -1) 

994 slice2[axis] = slice(None, -2) 

995 slice3[axis] = slice(1, -1) 

996 slice4[axis] = slice(2, None) 

997 

998 if uniform_spacing: 

999 out[tuple(slice1)] = (f[tuple(slice4)] - f[tuple(slice2)]) / (2. * ax_dx) 

1000 else: 

1001 dx1 = ax_dx[0:-1] 

1002 dx2 = ax_dx[1:] 

1003 a = -(dx2)/(dx1 * (dx1 + dx2)) 

1004 b = (dx2 - dx1) / (dx1 * dx2) 

1005 c = dx1 / (dx2 * (dx1 + dx2)) 

1006 # fix the shape for broadcasting 

1007 shape = np.ones(N, dtype=int) 

1008 shape[axis] = -1 

1009 a.shape = b.shape = c.shape = shape 

1010 # 1D equivalent -- out[1:-1] = a * f[:-2] + b * f[1:-1] + c * f[2:] 

1011 out[tuple(slice1)] = a * f[tuple(slice2)] + b * f[tuple(slice3)] + c * f[tuple(slice4)] 

1012 

1013 # Numerical differentiation: 1st order edges 

1014 if edge_order == 1: 

1015 slice1[axis] = 0 

1016 slice2[axis] = 1 

1017 slice3[axis] = 0 

1018 dx_0 = ax_dx if uniform_spacing else ax_dx[0] 

1019 # 1D equivalent -- out[0] = (f[1] - f[0]) / (x[1] - x[0]) 

1020 out[tuple(slice1)] = (f[tuple(slice2)] - f[tuple(slice3)]) / dx_0 

1021 

1022 slice1[axis] = -1 

1023 slice2[axis] = -1 

1024 slice3[axis] = -2 

1025 dx_n = ax_dx if uniform_spacing else ax_dx[-1] 

1026 # 1D equivalent -- out[-1] = (f[-1] - f[-2]) / (x[-1] - x[-2]) 

1027 out[tuple(slice1)] = (f[tuple(slice2)] - f[tuple(slice3)]) / dx_n 

1028 

1029 # Numerical differentiation: 2nd order edges 

1030 else: 

1031 slice1[axis] = 0 

1032 slice2[axis] = 0 

1033 slice3[axis] = 1 

1034 slice4[axis] = 2 

1035 if uniform_spacing: 

1036 a = -1.5 / ax_dx 

1037 b = 2. / ax_dx 

1038 c = -0.5 / ax_dx 

1039 else: 

1040 dx1 = ax_dx[0] 

1041 dx2 = ax_dx[1] 

1042 a = -(2. * dx1 + dx2)/(dx1 * (dx1 + dx2)) 

1043 b = (dx1 + dx2) / (dx1 * dx2) 

1044 c = - dx1 / (dx2 * (dx1 + dx2)) 

1045 # 1D equivalent -- out[0] = a * f[0] + b * f[1] + c * f[2] 

1046 out[tuple(slice1)] = a * f[tuple(slice2)] + b * f[tuple(slice3)] + c * f[tuple(slice4)] 

1047 

1048 slice1[axis] = -1 

1049 slice2[axis] = -3 

1050 slice3[axis] = -2 

1051 slice4[axis] = -1 

1052 if uniform_spacing: 

1053 a = 0.5 / ax_dx 

1054 b = -2. / ax_dx 

1055 c = 1.5 / ax_dx 

1056 else: 

1057 dx1 = ax_dx[-2] 

1058 dx2 = ax_dx[-1] 

1059 a = (dx2) / (dx1 * (dx1 + dx2)) 

1060 b = - (dx2 + dx1) / (dx1 * dx2) 

1061 c = (2. * dx2 + dx1) / (dx2 * (dx1 + dx2)) 

1062 # 1D equivalent -- out[-1] = a * f[-3] + b * f[-2] + c * f[-1] 

1063 out[tuple(slice1)] = a * f[tuple(slice2)] + b * f[tuple(slice3)] + c * f[tuple(slice4)] 

1064 

1065 outvals.append(out) 

1066 

1067 # reset the slice object in this dimension to ":" 

1068 slice1[axis] = slice(None) 

1069 slice2[axis] = slice(None) 

1070 slice3[axis] = slice(None) 

1071 slice4[axis] = slice(None) 

1072 

1073 if len_axes == 1: 

1074 return outvals[0] 

1075 else: 

1076 return outvals 

1077 

1078 

1079def diff(a, n=1, axis=-1): 

1080 """ 

1081 Calculate the n-th discrete difference along the given axis. 

1082 

1083 The first difference is given by ``out[n] = a[n+1] - a[n]`` along 

1084 the given axis, higher differences are calculated by using `diff` 

1085 recursively. 

1086 

1087 Parameters 

1088 ---------- 

1089 a : array_like 

1090 Input array 

1091 n : int, optional 

1092 The number of times values are differenced. If zero, the input 

1093 is returned as-is. 

1094 axis : int, optional 

1095 The axis along which the difference is taken, default is the 

1096 last axis. 

1097 

1098 Returns 

1099 ------- 

1100 diff : ndarray 

1101 The n-th differences. The shape of the output is the same as `a` 

1102 except along `axis` where the dimension is smaller by `n`. The 

1103 type of the output is the same as the type of the difference 

1104 between any two elements of `a`. This is the same as the type of 

1105 `a` in most cases. A notable exception is `datetime64`, which 

1106 results in a `timedelta64` output array. 

1107 

1108 See Also 

1109 -------- 

1110 gradient, ediff1d, cumsum 

1111 

1112 Notes 

1113 ----- 

1114 Type is preserved for boolean arrays, so the result will contain 

1115 `False` when consecutive elements are the same and `True` when they 

1116 differ. 

1117 

1118 For unsigned integer arrays, the results will also be unsigned. This 

1119 should not be surprising, as the result is consistent with 

1120 calculating the difference directly: 

1121 

1122 >>> u8_arr = np.array([1, 0], dtype=np.uint8) 

1123 >>> np.diff(u8_arr) 

1124 array([255], dtype=uint8) 

1125 >>> u8_arr[1,...] - u8_arr[0,...] 

1126 array(255, np.uint8) 

1127 

1128 If this is not desirable, then the array should be cast to a larger 

1129 integer type first: 

1130 

1131 >>> i16_arr = u8_arr.astype(np.int16) 

1132 >>> np.diff(i16_arr) 

1133 array([-1], dtype=int16) 

1134 

1135 Examples 

1136 -------- 

1137 >>> x = np.array([1, 2, 4, 7, 0]) 

1138 >>> np.diff(x) 

1139 array([ 1, 2, 3, -7]) 

1140 >>> np.diff(x, n=2) 

1141 array([ 1, 1, -10]) 

1142 

1143 >>> x = np.array([[1, 3, 6, 10], [0, 5, 6, 8]]) 

1144 >>> np.diff(x) 

1145 array([[2, 3, 4], 

1146 [5, 1, 2]]) 

1147 >>> np.diff(x, axis=0) 

1148 array([[-1, 2, 0, -2]]) 

1149 

1150 >>> x = np.arange('1066-10-13', '1066-10-16', dtype=np.datetime64) 

1151 >>> np.diff(x) 

1152 array([1, 1], dtype='timedelta64[D]') 

1153 

1154 """ 

1155 if n == 0: 

1156 return a 

1157 if n < 0: 

1158 raise ValueError( 

1159 "order must be non-negative but got " + repr(n)) 

1160 

1161 a = asanyarray(a) 

1162 nd = a.ndim 

1163 axis = normalize_axis_index(axis, nd) 

1164 

1165 slice1 = [slice(None)] * nd 

1166 slice2 = [slice(None)] * nd 

1167 slice1[axis] = slice(1, None) 

1168 slice2[axis] = slice(None, -1) 

1169 slice1 = tuple(slice1) 

1170 slice2 = tuple(slice2) 

1171 

1172 op = not_equal if a.dtype == np.bool_ else subtract 

1173 for _ in range(n): 

1174 a = op(a[slice1], a[slice2]) 

1175 

1176 return a 

1177 

1178 

1179def interp(x, xp, fp, left=None, right=None, period=None): 

1180 """ 

1181 One-dimensional linear interpolation. 

1182 

1183 Returns the one-dimensional piecewise linear interpolant to a function 

1184 with given discrete data points (`xp`, `fp`), evaluated at `x`. 

1185 

1186 Parameters 

1187 ---------- 

1188 x : array_like 

1189 The x-coordinates at which to evaluate the interpolated values. 

1190 

1191 xp : 1-D sequence of floats 

1192 The x-coordinates of the data points, must be increasing if argument 

1193 `period` is not specified. Otherwise, `xp` is internally sorted after 

1194 normalizing the periodic boundaries with ``xp = xp % period``. 

1195 

1196 fp : 1-D sequence of float or complex 

1197 The y-coordinates of the data points, same length as `xp`. 

1198 

1199 left : optional float or complex corresponding to fp 

1200 Value to return for `x < xp[0]`, default is `fp[0]`. 

1201 

1202 right : optional float or complex corresponding to fp 

1203 Value to return for `x > xp[-1]`, default is `fp[-1]`. 

1204 

1205 period : None or float, optional 

1206 A period for the x-coordinates. This parameter allows the proper 

1207 interpolation of angular x-coordinates. Parameters `left` and `right` 

1208 are ignored if `period` is specified. 

1209 

1210 .. versionadded:: 1.10.0 

1211 

1212 Returns 

1213 ------- 

1214 y : float or complex (corresponding to fp) or ndarray 

1215 The interpolated values, same shape as `x`. 

1216 

1217 Raises 

1218 ------ 

1219 ValueError 

1220 If `xp` and `fp` have different length 

1221 If `xp` or `fp` are not 1-D sequences 

1222 If `period == 0` 

1223 

1224 Notes 

1225 ----- 

1226 Does not check that the x-coordinate sequence `xp` is increasing. 

1227 If `xp` is not increasing, the results are nonsense. 

1228 A simple check for increasing is:: 

1229 

1230 np.all(np.diff(xp) > 0) 

1231 

1232 Examples 

1233 -------- 

1234 >>> xp = [1, 2, 3] 

1235 >>> fp = [3, 2, 0] 

1236 >>> np.interp(2.5, xp, fp) 

1237 1.0 

1238 >>> np.interp([0, 1, 1.5, 2.72, 3.14], xp, fp) 

1239 array([ 3. , 3. , 2.5 , 0.56, 0. ]) 

1240 >>> UNDEF = -99.0 

1241 >>> np.interp(3.14, xp, fp, right=UNDEF) 

1242 -99.0 

1243 

1244 Plot an interpolant to the sine function: 

1245 

1246 >>> x = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, 10) 

1247 >>> y = np.sin(x) 

1248 >>> xvals = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, 50) 

1249 >>> yinterp = np.interp(xvals, x, y) 

1250 >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

1251 >>> plt.plot(x, y, 'o') 

1252 [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x...>] 

1253 >>> plt.plot(xvals, yinterp, '-x') 

1254 [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x...>] 

1255 >>> plt.show() 

1256 

1257 Interpolation with periodic x-coordinates: 

1258 

1259 >>> x = [-180, -170, -185, 185, -10, -5, 0, 365] 

1260 >>> xp = [190, -190, 350, -350] 

1261 >>> fp = [5, 10, 3, 4] 

1262 >>> np.interp(x, xp, fp, period=360) 

1263 array([7.5, 5., 8.75, 6.25, 3., 3.25, 3.5, 3.75]) 

1264 

1265 Complex interpolation: 

1266 

1267 >>> x = [1.5, 4.0] 

1268 >>> xp = [2,3,5] 

1269 >>> fp = [1.0j, 0, 2+3j] 

1270 >>> np.interp(x, xp, fp) 

1271 array([ 0.+1.j , 1.+1.5j]) 

1272 

1273 """ 

1274 

1275 fp = np.asarray(fp) 

1276 

1277 if np.iscomplexobj(fp): 

1278 interp_func = compiled_interp_complex 

1279 input_dtype = np.complex128 

1280 else: 

1281 interp_func = compiled_interp 

1282 input_dtype = np.float64 

1283 

1284 if period is not None: 

1285 if period == 0: 

1286 raise ValueError("period must be a non-zero value") 

1287 period = abs(period) 

1288 left = None 

1289 right = None 

1290 

1291 x = np.asarray(x, dtype=np.float64) 

1292 xp = np.asarray(xp, dtype=np.float64) 

1293 fp = np.asarray(fp, dtype=input_dtype) 

1294 

1295 if xp.ndim != 1 or fp.ndim != 1: 

1296 raise ValueError("Data points must be 1-D sequences") 

1297 if xp.shape[0] != fp.shape[0]: 

1298 raise ValueError("fp and xp are not of the same length") 

1299 # normalizing periodic boundaries 

1300 x = x % period 

1301 xp = xp % period 

1302 asort_xp = np.argsort(xp) 

1303 xp = xp[asort_xp] 

1304 fp = fp[asort_xp] 

1305 xp = np.concatenate((xp[-1:]-period, xp, xp[0:1]+period)) 

1306 fp = np.concatenate((fp[-1:], fp, fp[0:1])) 

1307 

1308 return interp_func(x, xp, fp, left, right) 

1309 

1310 

1311def angle(z, deg=0): 

1312 """ 

1313 Return the angle of the complex argument. 

1314 

1315 Parameters 

1316 ---------- 

1317 z : array_like 

1318 A complex number or sequence of complex numbers. 

1319 deg : bool, optional 

1320 Return angle in degrees if True, radians if False (default). 

1321 

1322 Returns 

1323 ------- 

1324 angle : ndarray or scalar 

1325 The counterclockwise angle from the positive real axis on 

1326 the complex plane, with dtype as numpy.float64. 

1327 

1328 See Also 

1329 -------- 

1330 arctan2 

1331 absolute 

1332 

1333 Examples 

1334 -------- 

1335 >>> np.angle([1.0, 1.0j, 1+1j]) # in radians 

1336 array([ 0. , 1.57079633, 0.78539816]) 

1337 >>> np.angle(1+1j, deg=True) # in degrees 

1338 45.0 

1339 

1340 """ 

1341 if deg: 

1342 fact = 180/pi 

1343 else: 

1344 fact = 1.0 

1345 z = asarray(z) 

1346 if (issubclass(z.dtype.type, _nx.complexfloating)): 

1347 zimag = z.imag 

1348 zreal = z.real 

1349 else: 

1350 zimag = 0 

1351 zreal = z 

1352 return arctan2(zimag, zreal) * fact 

1353 

1354 

1355def unwrap(p, discont=pi, axis=-1): 

1356 """ 

1357 Unwrap by changing deltas between values to 2*pi complement. 

1358 

1359 Unwrap radian phase `p` by changing absolute jumps greater than 

1360 `discont` to their 2*pi complement along the given axis. 

1361 

1362 Parameters 

1363 ---------- 

1364 p : array_like 

1365 Input array. 

1366 discont : float, optional 

1367 Maximum discontinuity between values, default is ``pi``. 

1368 axis : int, optional 

1369 Axis along which unwrap will operate, default is the last axis. 

1370 

1371 Returns 

1372 ------- 

1373 out : ndarray 

1374 Output array. 

1375 

1376 See Also 

1377 -------- 

1378 rad2deg, deg2rad 

1379 

1380 Notes 

1381 ----- 

1382 If the discontinuity in `p` is smaller than ``pi``, but larger than 

1383 `discont`, no unwrapping is done because taking the 2*pi complement 

1384 would only make the discontinuity larger. 

1385 

1386 Examples 

1387 -------- 

1388 >>> phase = np.linspace(0, np.pi, num=5) 

1389 >>> phase[3:] += np.pi 

1390 >>> phase 

1391 array([ 0. , 0.78539816, 1.57079633, 5.49778714, 6.28318531]) 

1392 >>> np.unwrap(phase) 

1393 array([ 0. , 0.78539816, 1.57079633, -0.78539816, 0. ]) 

1394 

1395 """ 

1396 p = asarray(p) 

1397 nd = p.ndim 

1398 dd = diff(p, axis=axis) 

1399 slice1 = [slice(None, None)]*nd # full slices 

1400 slice1[axis] = slice(1, None) 

1401 slice1 = tuple(slice1) 

1402 ddmod = mod(dd + pi, 2*pi) - pi 

1403 _nx.copyto(ddmod, pi, where=(ddmod == -pi) & (dd > 0)) 

1404 ph_correct = ddmod - dd 

1405 _nx.copyto(ph_correct, 0, where=abs(dd) < discont) 

1406 up = array(p, copy=True, dtype='d') 

1407 up[slice1] = p[slice1] + ph_correct.cumsum(axis) 

1408 return up 

1409 

1410 

1411def sort_complex(a): 

1412 """ 

1413 Sort a complex array using the real part first, then the imaginary part. 

1414 

1415 Parameters 

1416 ---------- 

1417 a : array_like 

1418 Input array 

1419 

1420 Returns 

1421 ------- 

1422 out : complex ndarray 

1423 Always returns a sorted complex array. 

1424 

1425 Examples 

1426 -------- 

1427 >>> np.sort_complex([5, 3, 6, 2, 1]) 

1428 array([ 1.+0.j, 2.+0.j, 3.+0.j, 5.+0.j, 6.+0.j]) 

1429 

1430 >>> np.sort_complex([1 + 2j, 2 - 1j, 3 - 2j, 3 - 3j, 3 + 5j]) 

1431 array([ 1.+2.j, 2.-1.j, 3.-3.j, 3.-2.j, 3.+5.j]) 

1432 

1433 """ 

1434 b = array(a, copy=True) 

1435 b.sort() 

1436 if not issubclass(b.dtype.type, _nx.complexfloating): 

1437 if b.dtype.char in 'bhBH': 

1438 return b.astype('F') 

1439 elif b.dtype.char == 'g': 

1440 return b.astype('G') 

1441 else: 

1442 return b.astype('D') 

1443 else: 

1444 return b

1446 

1447def trim_zeros(filt, trim='fb'): 

1448 """ 

1449 Trim the leading and/or trailing zeros from a 1-D array or sequence. 

1450 

1451 Parameters 

1452 ---------- 

1453 filt : 1-D array or sequence 

1454 Input array. 

1455 trim : str, optional 

1456 A string with 'f' representing trim from front and 'b' to trim from 

1457 back. Default is 'fb', trim zeros from both front and back of the 

1458 array. 

1459 

1460 Returns 

1461 ------- 

1462 trimmed : 1-D array or sequence 

1463 The result of trimming the input. The input data type is preserved. 

1464 

1465 Examples 

1466 -------- 

1467 >>> a = np.array((0, 0, 0, 1, 2, 3, 0, 2, 1, 0)) 

1468 >>> np.trim_zeros(a) 

1469 array([1, 2, 3, 0, 2, 1]) 

1470 

1471 >>> np.trim_zeros(a, 'b') 

1472 array([0, 0, 0, 1, 2, 3, 0, 2, 1]) 

1473 

1474 The input data type is preserved, list/tuple in means list/tuple out. 

1475 

1476 >>> np.trim_zeros([0, 1, 2, 0]) 

1477 [1, 2] 

1478 

1479 """ 

1480 first = 0 

1481 trim = trim.upper() 

1482 if 'F' in trim: 

1483 for i in filt: 

1484 if i != 0.: 

1485 break 

1486 else: 

1487 first = first + 1 

1488 last = len(filt) 

1489 if 'B' in trim: 

1490 for i in filt[::-1]: 

1491 if i != 0.: 

1492 break 

1493 else: 

1494 last = last - 1 

1495 return filt[first:last] 

1496 

1497 

1498@deprecate 

1499def unique(x): 

1500 """ 

1501 This function is deprecated. Use numpy.lib.arraysetops.unique() 

1502 instead. 

1503 """ 

1504 try: 

1505 tmp = x.flatten() 

1506 if tmp.size == 0: 

1507 return tmp 

1508 tmp.sort() 

1509 idx = concatenate(([True], tmp[1:] != tmp[:-1])) 

1510 return tmp[idx] 

1511 except AttributeError: 

1512 items = sorted(set(x)) 

1513 return asarray(items)
