1515 

1516def extract(condition, arr): 

1517 """ 

1518 Return the elements of an array that satisfy some condition. 

1519 

1520 This is equivalent to ``np.compress(ravel(condition), ravel(arr))``. If 

1521 `condition` is boolean ``np.extract`` is equivalent to ``arr[condition]``. 

1522 

1523 Note that `place` does the exact opposite of `extract`. 

1524 

1525 Parameters 

1526 ---------- 

1527 condition : array_like 

1528 An array whose nonzero or True entries indicate the elements of `arr` 

1529 to extract. 

1530 arr : array_like 

1531 Input array of the same size as `condition`. 

1532 

1533 Returns 

1534 ------- 

1535 extract : ndarray 

1536 Rank 1 array of values from `arr` where `condition` is True. 

1537 

1538 See Also 

1539 -------- 

1540 take, put, copyto, compress, place 

1541 

1542 Examples 

1543 -------- 

1544 >>> arr = np.arange(12).reshape((3, 4)) 

1545 >>> arr 

1546 array([[ 0, 1, 2, 3], 

1547 [ 4, 5, 6, 7], 

1548 [ 8, 9, 10, 11]]) 

1549 >>> condition = np.mod(arr, 3)==0 

1550 >>> condition 

1551 array([[ True, False, False, True], 

1552 [False, False, True, False], 

1553 [False, True, False, False]]) 

1554 >>> np.extract(condition, arr) 

1555 array([0, 3, 6, 9]) 

1556 

1557 

1558 If `condition` is boolean: 

1559 

1560 >>> arr[condition] 

1561 array([0, 3, 6, 9]) 

1562 

1563 """ 

1564 return _nx.take(ravel(arr), nonzero(ravel(condition))[0]) 

1565 

1566 

1567def place(arr, mask, vals): 

1568 """ 

1569 Change elements of an array based on conditional and input values. 

1570 

1571 Similar to ``np.copyto(arr, vals, where=mask)``, the difference is that 

1572 `place` uses the first N elements of `vals`, where N is the number of 

1573 True values in `mask`, while `copyto` uses the elements where `mask` 

1574 is True. 

1575 

1576 Note that `extract` does the exact opposite of `place`. 

1577 

1578 Parameters 

1579 ---------- 

1580 arr : ndarray 

1581 Array to put data into. 

1582 mask : array_like 

1583 Boolean mask array. Must have the same size as `a`. 

1584 vals : 1-D sequence 

1585 Values to put into `a`. Only the first N elements are used, where 

1586 N is the number of True values in `mask`. If `vals` is smaller 

1587 than N, it will be repeated, and if elements of `a` are to be masked, 

1588 this sequence must be non-empty. 

1589 

1590 See Also 

1591 -------- 

1592 copyto, put, take, extract 

1593 

1594 Examples 

1595 -------- 

1596 >>> arr = np.arange(6).reshape(2, 3) 

1597 >>> np.place(arr, arr>2, [44, 55]) 

1598 >>> arr 

1599 array([[ 0, 1, 2], 

1600 [44, 55, 44]]) 

1601 

1602 """ 

1603 if not isinstance(arr, np.ndarray): 

1604 raise TypeError("argument 1 must be numpy.ndarray, " 

1605 "not {name}".format(name=type(arr).__name__)) 

1606 

1607 return _insert(arr, mask, vals) 

1608 

1609 

1610def disp(mesg, device=None, linefeed=True): 

1611 """ 

1612 Display a message on a device. 

1613 

1614 Parameters 

1615 ---------- 

1616 mesg : str 

1617 Message to display. 

1618 device : object 

1619 Device to write message. If None, defaults to ``sys.stdout`` which is 

1620 very similar to ``print``. `device` needs to have ``write()`` and 

1621 ``flush()`` methods. 

1622 linefeed : bool, optional 

1623 Option whether to print a line feed or not. Defaults to True. 

1624 

1625 Raises 

1626 ------ 

1627 AttributeError 

1628 If `device` does not have a ``write()`` or ``flush()`` method. 

1629 

1630 Examples 

1631 -------- 

1632 Besides ``sys.stdout``, a file-like object can also be used as it has 

1633 both required methods: 

1634 

1635 >>> from io import StringIO 

1636 >>> buf = StringIO() 

1637 >>> np.disp(u'"Display" in a file', device=buf) 

1638 >>> buf.getvalue() 

1639 '"Display" in a file\\n' 

1640 

1641 """ 

1642 if device is None: 

1643 device = sys.stdout 

1644 if linefeed: 

1645 device.write('%s\n' % mesg) 

1646 else: 

1647 device.write('%s' % mesg) 

1648 device.flush() 

1649 return 

1650 

1651 

1652# See http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/c-api.generalized-ufuncs.html 

1653_DIMENSION_NAME = r'\w+' 

1654_CORE_DIMENSION_LIST = '(?:{0:}(?:,{0:})*)?'.format(_DIMENSION_NAME) 

1655_ARGUMENT = r'\({}\)'.format(_CORE_DIMENSION_LIST) 

1656_ARGUMENT_LIST = '{0:}(?:,{0:})*'.format(_ARGUMENT) 

1657_SIGNATURE = '^{0:}->{0:}$'.format(_ARGUMENT_LIST) 

1658 

1659 

1660def _parse_gufunc_signature(signature): 

1661 """ 

1662 Parse string signatures for a generalized universal function. 

1663 

1664 Arguments 

1665 --------- 

1666 signature : string 

1667 Generalized universal function signature, e.g., ``(m,n),(n,p)->(m,p)`` 

1668 for ``np.matmul``. 

1669 

1670 Returns 

1671 ------- 

1672 Tuple of input and output core dimensions parsed from the signature, each 

1673 of the form List[Tuple[str, ...]]. 

1674 """ 

1675 if not re.match(_SIGNATURE, signature): 

1676 raise ValueError( 

1677 'not a valid gufunc signature: {}'.format(signature)) 

1678 return tuple([tuple(re.findall(_DIMENSION_NAME, arg)) 

1679 for arg in re.findall(_ARGUMENT, arg_list)] 

1680 for arg_list in signature.split('->')) 

1681 

1682 

1683def _update_dim_sizes(dim_sizes, arg, core_dims): 

1684 """ 

1685 Incrementally check and update core dimension sizes for a single argument. 

1686 

1687 Arguments 

1688 --------- 

1689 dim_sizes : Dict[str, int] 

1690 Sizes of existing core dimensions. Will be updated in-place. 

1691 arg : ndarray 

1692 Argument to examine. 

1693 core_dims : Tuple[str, ...] 

1694 Core dimensions for this argument. 

1695 """ 

1696 if not core_dims: 

1697 return 

1698 

1699 num_core_dims = len(core_dims) 

1700 if arg.ndim < num_core_dims: 

1701 raise ValueError( 

1702 '%d-dimensional argument does not have enough ' 

1703 'dimensions for all core dimensions %r' 

1704 % (arg.ndim, core_dims)) 

1705 

1706 core_shape = arg.shape[-num_core_dims:] 

1707 for dim, size in zip(core_dims, core_shape): 

1708 if dim in dim_sizes: 

1709 if size != dim_sizes[dim]: 

1710 raise ValueError( 

1711 'inconsistent size for core dimension %r: %r vs %r' 

1712 % (dim, size, dim_sizes[dim])) 

1713 else: 

1714 dim_sizes[dim] = size 

1715 

1716 

1717def _parse_input_dimensions(args, input_core_dims): 

1718 """ 

1719 Parse broadcast and core dimensions for vectorize with a signature. 

1720 

1721 Arguments 

1722 --------- 

1723 args : Tuple[ndarray, ...] 

1724 Tuple of input arguments to examine. 

1725 input_core_dims : List[Tuple[str, ...]] 

1726 List of core dimensions corresponding to each input. 

1727 

1728 Returns 

1729 ------- 

1730 broadcast_shape : Tuple[int, ...] 

1731 Common shape to broadcast all non-core dimensions to. 

1732 dim_sizes : Dict[str, int] 

1733 Common sizes for named core dimensions. 

1734 """ 

1735 broadcast_args = [] 

1736 dim_sizes = {} 

1737 for arg, core_dims in zip(args, input_core_dims): 

1738 _update_dim_sizes(dim_sizes, arg, core_dims) 

1739 ndim = arg.ndim - len(core_dims) 

1740 dummy_array = np.lib.stride_tricks.as_strided(0, arg.shape[:ndim]) 

1741 broadcast_args.append(dummy_array) 

1742 broadcast_shape = np.lib.stride_tricks._broadcast_shape(*broadcast_args) 

1743 return broadcast_shape, dim_sizes 

1744 

1745 

1746def _calculate_shapes(broadcast_shape, dim_sizes, list_of_core_dims): 

1747 """Helper for calculating broadcast shapes with core dimensions.""" 

1748 return [broadcast_shape + tuple(dim_sizes[dim] for dim in core_dims) 

1749 for core_dims in list_of_core_dims] 

1750 

1751 

1752def _create_arrays(broadcast_shape, dim_sizes, list_of_core_dims, dtypes): 

1753 """Helper for creating output arrays in vectorize.""" 

1754 shapes = _calculate_shapes(broadcast_shape, dim_sizes, list_of_core_dims) 

1755 arrays = tuple(np.empty(shape, dtype=dtype) 

1756 for shape, dtype in zip(shapes, dtypes)) 

1757 return arrays 

1758 

1759 

1760class vectorize(object): 

1761 """ 

1762 vectorize(pyfunc, otypes=None, doc=None, excluded=None, cache=False, 

1763 signature=None) 

1764 

1765 Generalized function class. 

1766 

1767 Define a vectorized function which takes a nested sequence of objects or 

1768 numpy arrays as inputs and returns an single or tuple of numpy array as 

1769 output. The vectorized function evaluates `pyfunc` over successive tuples 

1770 of the input arrays like the python map function, except it uses the 

1771 broadcasting rules of numpy. 

1772 

1773 The data type of the output of `vectorized` is determined by calling 

1774 the function with the first element of the input. This can be avoided 

1775 by specifying the `otypes` argument. 

1776 

1777 Parameters 

1778 ---------- 

1779 pyfunc : callable 

1780 A python function or method. 

1781 otypes : str or list of dtypes, optional 

1782 The output data type. It must be specified as either a string of 

1783 typecode characters or a list of data type specifiers. There should 

1784 be one data type specifier for each output. 

1785 doc : str, optional 

1786 The docstring for the function. If `None`, the docstring will be the 

1787 ``pyfunc.__doc__``. 

1788 excluded : set, optional 

1789 Set of strings or integers representing the positional or keyword 

1790 arguments for which the function will not be vectorized. These will be 

1791 passed directly to `pyfunc` unmodified. 

1792 

1793 .. versionadded:: 1.7.0 

1794 

1795 cache : bool, optional 

1796 If `True`, then cache the first function call that determines the number 

1797 of outputs if `otypes` is not provided. 

1798 

1799 .. versionadded:: 1.7.0 

1800 

1801 signature : string, optional 

1802 Generalized universal function signature, e.g., ``(m,n),(n)->(m)`` for 

1803 vectorized matrix-vector multiplication. If provided, ``pyfunc`` will 

1804 be called with (and expected to return) arrays with shapes given by the 

1805 size of corresponding core dimensions. By default, ``pyfunc`` is 

1806 assumed to take scalars as input and output. 

1807 

1808 .. versionadded:: 1.12.0 

1809 

1810 Returns 

1811 ------- 

1812 vectorized : callable 

1813 Vectorized function. 

1814 

1815 Examples 

1816 -------- 

1817 >>> def myfunc(a, b): 

1818 ... "Return a-b if a>b, otherwise return a+b" 

1819 ... if a > b: 

1820 ... return a - b 

1821 ... else: 

1822 ... return a + b 

1823 

1824 >>> vfunc = np.vectorize(myfunc) 

1825 >>> vfunc([1, 2, 3, 4], 2) 

1826 array([3, 4, 1, 2]) 

1827 

1828 The docstring is taken from the input function to `vectorize` unless it 

1829 is specified: 

1830 

1831 >>> vfunc.__doc__ 

1832 'Return a-b if a>b, otherwise return a+b' 

1833 >>> vfunc = np.vectorize(myfunc, doc='Vectorized `myfunc`') 

1834 >>> vfunc.__doc__ 

1835 'Vectorized `myfunc`' 

1836 

1837 The output type is determined by evaluating the first element of the input, 

1838 unless it is specified: 

1839 

1840 >>> out = vfunc([1, 2, 3, 4], 2) 

1841 >>> type(out[0]) 

1842 <type 'numpy.int32'> 

1843 >>> vfunc = np.vectorize(myfunc, otypes=[float]) 

1844 >>> out = vfunc([1, 2, 3, 4], 2) 

1845 >>> type(out[0]) 

1846 <type 'numpy.float64'> 

1847 

1848 The `excluded` argument can be used to prevent vectorizing over certain 

1849 arguments. This can be useful for array-like arguments of a fixed length 

1850 such as the coefficients for a polynomial as in `polyval`: 

1851 

1852 >>> def mypolyval(p, x): 

1853 ... _p = list(p) 

1854 ... res = _p.pop(0) 

1855 ... while _p: 

1856 ... res = res*x + _p.pop(0) 

1857 ... return res 

1858 >>> vpolyval = np.vectorize(mypolyval, excluded=['p']) 

1859 >>> vpolyval(p=[1, 2, 3], x=[0, 1]) 

1860 array([3, 6]) 

1861 

1862 Positional arguments may also be excluded by specifying their position: 

1863 

1864 >>> vpolyval.excluded.add(0) 

1865 >>> vpolyval([1, 2, 3], x=[0, 1]) 

1866 array([3, 6]) 

1867 

1868 The `signature` argument allows for vectorizing functions that act on 

1869 non-scalar arrays of fixed length. For example, you can use it for a 

1870 vectorized calculation of Pearson correlation coefficient and its p-value: 

1871 

1872 >>> import scipy.stats 

1873 >>> pearsonr = np.vectorize(scipy.stats.pearsonr, 

1874 ... signature='(n),(n)->(),()') 

1875 >>> pearsonr([[0, 1, 2, 3]], [[1, 2, 3, 4], [4, 3, 2, 1]]) 

1876 (array([ 1., -1.]), array([ 0., 0.])) 

1877 

1878 Or for a vectorized convolution: 

1879 

1880 >>> convolve = np.vectorize(np.convolve, signature='(n),(m)->(k)') 

1881 >>> convolve(np.eye(4), [1, 2, 1]) 

1882 array([[ 1., 2., 1., 0., 0., 0.], 

1883 [ 0., 1., 2., 1., 0., 0.], 

1884 [ 0., 0., 1., 2., 1., 0.], 

1885 [ 0., 0., 0., 1., 2., 1.]]) 

1886 

1887 See Also 

1888 -------- 

1889 frompyfunc : Takes an arbitrary Python function and returns a ufunc 

1890 

1891 Notes 

1892 ----- 

1893 The `vectorize` function is provided primarily for convenience, not for 

1894 performance. The implementation is essentially a for loop. 

1895 

1896 If `otypes` is not specified, then a call to the function with the 

1897 first argument will be used to determine the number of outputs. The 

1898 results of this call will be cached if `cache` is `True` to prevent 

1899 calling the function twice. However, to implement the cache, the 

1900 original function must be wrapped which will slow down subsequent 

1901 calls, so only do this if your function is expensive. 

1902 

1903 The new keyword argument interface and `excluded` argument support 

1904 further degrades performance. 

1905 

1906 References 

1907 ---------- 

1908 .. [1] NumPy Reference, section `Generalized Universal Function API 

1909 <http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/c-api.generalized-ufuncs.html>`_. 

1910 """ 

1911 

1912 def __init__(self, pyfunc, otypes=None, doc=None, excluded=None, 

1913 cache=False, signature=None): 

1914 self.pyfunc = pyfunc 

1915 self.cache = cache 

1916 self.signature = signature 

1917 self._ufunc = None # Caching to improve default performance 

1918 

1919 if doc is None: 

1920 self.__doc__ = pyfunc.__doc__ 

1921 else: 

1922 self.__doc__ = doc 

1923 

1924 if isinstance(otypes, str): 

1925 for char in otypes: 

1926 if char not in typecodes['All']: 

1927 raise ValueError("Invalid otype specified: %s" % (char,)) 

1928 elif iterable(otypes): 

1929 otypes = ''.join([_nx.dtype(x).char for x in otypes]) 

1930 elif otypes is not None: 

1931 raise ValueError("Invalid otype specification") 

1932 self.otypes = otypes 

1933 

1934 # Excluded variable support 

1935 if excluded is None: 

1936 excluded = set() 

1937 self.excluded = set(excluded) 

1938 

1939 if signature is not None: 

1940 self._in_and_out_core_dims = _parse_gufunc_signature(signature) 

1941 else: 

1942 self._in_and_out_core_dims = None 

1943 

1944 def __call__(self, *args, **kwargs): 

1945 """ 

1946 Return arrays with the results of `pyfunc` broadcast (vectorized) over 

1947 `args` and `kwargs` not in `excluded`. 

1948 """ 

1949 excluded = self.excluded 

1950 if not kwargs and not excluded: 

1951 func = self.pyfunc 

1952 vargs = args 

1953 else: 

1954 # The wrapper accepts only positional arguments: we use `names` and 

1955 # `inds` to mutate `the_args` and `kwargs` to pass to the original 

1956 # function. 

1957 nargs = len(args) 

1958 

1959 names = [_n for _n in kwargs if _n not in excluded] 

1960 inds = [_i for _i in range(nargs) if _i not in excluded] 

1961 the_args = list(args) 

1962 

1963 def func(*vargs): 

1964 for _n, _i in enumerate(inds): 

1965 the_args[_i] = vargs[_n] 

1966 kwargs.update(zip(names, vargs[len(inds):])) 

1967 return self.pyfunc(*the_args, **kwargs) 

1968 

1969 vargs = [args[_i] for _i in inds] 

1970 vargs.extend([kwargs[_n] for _n in names]) 

1971 

1972 return self._vectorize_call(func=func, args=vargs) 

1973 

1974 def _get_ufunc_and_otypes(self, func, args): 

1975 """Return (ufunc, otypes).""" 

1976 # frompyfunc will fail if args is empty 

1977 if not args: 

1978 raise ValueError('args can not be empty') 

1979 

1980 if self.otypes is not None: 

1981 otypes = self.otypes 

1982 nout = len(otypes) 

1983 

1984 # Note logic here: We only *use* self._ufunc if func is self.pyfunc 

1985 # even though we set self._ufunc regardless. 

1986 if func is self.pyfunc and self._ufunc is not None: 

1987 ufunc = self._ufunc 

1988 else: 

1989 ufunc = self._ufunc = frompyfunc(func, len(args), nout) 

1990 else: 

1991 # Get number of outputs and output types by calling the function on 

1992 # the first entries of args. We also cache the result to prevent 

1993 # the subsequent call when the ufunc is evaluated. 

1994 # Assumes that ufunc first evaluates the 0th elements in the input 

1995 # arrays (the input values are not checked to ensure this) 

1996 args = [asarray(arg) for arg in args] 

1997 if builtins.any(arg.size == 0 for arg in args): 

1998 raise ValueError('cannot call `vectorize` on size 0 inputs ' 

1999 'unless `otypes` is set') 

2000 

2001 inputs = [arg.flat[0] for arg in args] 

2002 outputs = func(*inputs) 

2003 

2004 # Performance note: profiling indicates that -- for simple 

2005 # functions at least -- this wrapping can almost double the 

2006 # execution time. 

2007 # Hence we make it optional. 

2008 if self.cache: 

2009 _cache = [outputs] 

2010 

2011 def _func(*vargs): 

2012 if _cache: 

2013 return _cache.pop() 

2014 else: 

2015 return func(*vargs) 

2016 else: 

2017 _func = func 

2018 

2019 if isinstance(outputs, tuple): 

2020 nout = len(outputs) 

2021 else: 

2022 nout = 1 

2023 outputs = (outputs,) 

2024 

2025 otypes = ''.join([asarray(outputs[_k]).dtype.char 

2026 for _k in range(nout)]) 

2027 

2028 # Performance note: profiling indicates that creating the ufunc is 

2029 # not a significant cost compared with wrapping so it seems not 

2030 # worth trying to cache this. 

2031 ufunc = frompyfunc(_func, len(args), nout) 

2032 

2033 return ufunc, otypes 

2034 

2035 def _vectorize_call(self, func, args): 

2036 """Vectorized call to `func` over positional `args`.""" 

2037 if self.signature is not None: 

2038 res = self._vectorize_call_with_signature(func, args) 

2039 elif not args: 

2040 res = func() 

2041 else: 

2042 ufunc, otypes = self._get_ufunc_and_otypes(func=func, args=args) 

2043 

2044 # Convert args to object arrays first 

2045 inputs = [array(a, copy=False, subok=True, dtype=object) 

2046 for a in args] 

2047 

2048 outputs = ufunc(*inputs) 

2049 

2050 if ufunc.nout == 1: 

2051 res = array(outputs, copy=False, subok=True, dtype=otypes[0]) 

2052 else: 

2053 res = tuple([array(x, copy=False, subok=True, dtype=t) 

2054 for x, t in zip(outputs, otypes)]) 

2055 return res 

2056 

2057 def _vectorize_call_with_signature(self, func, args): 

2058 """Vectorized call over positional arguments with a signature.""" 

2059 input_core_dims, output_core_dims = self._in_and_out_core_dims 

2060 

2061 if len(args) != len(input_core_dims): 

2062 raise TypeError('wrong number of positional arguments: ' 

2063 'expected %r, got %r' 

2064 % (len(input_core_dims), len(args))) 

2065 args = tuple(asanyarray(arg) for arg in args) 

2066 

2067 broadcast_shape, dim_sizes = _parse_input_dimensions( 

2068 args, input_core_dims) 

2069 input_shapes = _calculate_shapes(broadcast_shape, dim_sizes, 

2070 input_core_dims) 

2071 args = [np.broadcast_to(arg, shape, subok=True) 

2072 for arg, shape in zip(args, input_shapes)] 

2073 

2074 outputs = None 

2075 otypes = self.otypes 

2076 nout = len(output_core_dims) 

2077 

2078 for index in np.ndindex(*broadcast_shape): 

2079 results = func(*(arg[index] for arg in args)) 

2080 

2081 n_results = len(results) if isinstance(results, tuple) else 1 

2082 

2083 if nout != n_results: 

2084 raise ValueError( 

2085 'wrong number of outputs from pyfunc: expected %r, got %r' 

2086 % (nout, n_results)) 

2087 

2088 if nout == 1: 

2089 results = (results,) 

2090 

2091 if outputs is None: 

2092 for result, core_dims in zip(results, output_core_dims): 

2093 _update_dim_sizes(dim_sizes, result, core_dims) 

2094 

2095 if otypes is None: 

2096 otypes = [asarray(result).dtype for result in results] 

2097 

2098 outputs = _create_arrays(broadcast_shape, dim_sizes, 

2099 output_core_dims, otypes) 

2100 

2101 for output, result in zip(outputs, results): 

2102 output[index] = result 

2103 

2104 if outputs is None: 

2105 # did not call the function even once 

2106 if otypes is None: 

2107 raise ValueError('cannot call `vectorize` on size 0 inputs ' 

2108 'unless `otypes` is set') 

2109 if builtins.any(dim not in dim_sizes 

2110 for dims in output_core_dims 

2111 for dim in dims): 

2112 raise ValueError('cannot call `vectorize` with a signature ' 

2113 'including new output dimensions on size 0 ' 

2114 'inputs') 

2115 outputs = _create_arrays(broadcast_shape, dim_sizes, 

2116 output_core_dims, otypes) 

2117 

2118 return outputs[0] if nout == 1 else outputs 

2119 

2120 

2121def cov(m, y=None, rowvar=True, bias=False, ddof=None, fweights=None, 

2122 aweights=None): 

2123 """ 

2124 Estimate a covariance matrix, given data and weights. 

2125 

2126 Covariance indicates the level to which two variables vary together. 

2127 If we examine N-dimensional samples, :math:`X = [x_1, x_2, ... x_N]^T`, 

2128 then the covariance matrix element :math:`C_{ij}` is the covariance of 

2129 :math:`x_i` and :math:`x_j`. The element :math:`C_{ii}` is the variance 

2130 of :math:`x_i`. 

2131 

2132 See the notes for an outline of the algorithm. 

2133 

2134 Parameters 

2135 ---------- 

2136 m : array_like 

2137 A 1-D or 2-D array containing multiple variables and observations. 

2138 Each row of `m` represents a variable, and each column a single 

2139 observation of all those variables. Also see `rowvar` below. 

2140 y : array_like, optional 

2141 An additional set of variables and observations. `y` has the same form 

2142 as that of `m`. 

2143 rowvar : bool, optional 

2144 If `rowvar` is True (default), then each row represents a 

2145 variable, with observations in the columns. Otherwise, the relationship 

2146 is transposed: each column represents a variable, while the rows 

2147 contain observations. 

2148 bias : bool, optional 

2149 Default normalization (False) is by ``(N - 1)``, where ``N`` is the 

2150 number of observations given (unbiased estimate). If `bias` is True, 

2151 then normalization is by ``N``. These values can be overridden by using 

2152 the keyword ``ddof`` in numpy versions >= 1.5. 

2153 ddof : int, optional 

2154 If not ``None`` the default value implied by `bias` is overridden. 

2155 Note that ``ddof=1`` will return the unbiased estimate, even if both 

2156 `fweights` and `aweights` are specified, and ``ddof=0`` will return 

2157 the simple average. See the notes for the details. The default value 

2158 is ``None``. 

2159 

2160 .. versionadded:: 1.5 

2161 fweights : array_like, int, optional 

2162 1-D array of integer frequency weights; the number of times each 

2163 observation vector should be repeated. 

2164 

2165 .. versionadded:: 1.10 

2166 aweights : array_like, optional 

2167 1-D array of observation vector weights. These relative weights are 

2168 typically large for observations considered "important" and smaller for 

2169 observations considered less "important". If ``ddof=0`` the array of 

2170 weights can be used to assign probabilities to observation vectors. 

2171 

2172 .. versionadded:: 1.10 

2173 

2174 Returns 

2175 ------- 

2176 out : ndarray 

2177 The covariance matrix of the variables. 

2178 

2179 See Also 

2180 -------- 

2181 corrcoef : Normalized covariance matrix 

2182 

2183 Notes 

2184 ----- 

2185 Assume that the observations are in the columns of the observation 

2186 array `m` and let ``f = fweights`` and ``a = aweights`` for brevity. The 

2187 steps to compute the weighted covariance are as follows:: 

2188 

2189 >>> w = f * a 

2190 >>> v1 = np.sum(w) 

2191 >>> v2 = np.sum(w * a) 

2192 >>> m -= np.sum(m * w, axis=1, keepdims=True) / v1 

2193 >>> cov = np.dot(m * w, m.T) * v1 / (v1**2 - ddof * v2) 

2194 

2195 Note that when ``a == 1``, the normalization factor 

2196 ``v1 / (v1**2 - ddof * v2)`` goes over to ``1 / (np.sum(f) - ddof)`` 

2197 as it should. 

2198 

2199 Examples 

2200 -------- 

2201 Consider two variables, :math:`x_0` and :math:`x_1`, which 

2202 correlate perfectly, but in opposite directions: 

2203 

2204 >>> x = np.array([[0, 2], [1, 1], [2, 0]]).T 

2205 >>> x 

2206 array([[0, 1, 2], 

2207 [2, 1, 0]]) 

2208 

2209 Note how :math:`x_0` increases while :math:`x_1` decreases. The covariance 

2210 matrix shows this clearly: 

2211 

2212 >>> np.cov(x) 

2213 array([[ 1., -1.], 

2214 [-1., 1.]]) 

2215 

2216 Note that element :math:`C_{0,1}`, which shows the correlation between 

2217 :math:`x_0` and :math:`x_1`, is negative. 

2218 

2219 Further, note how `x` and `y` are combined: 

2220 

2221 >>> x = [-2.1, -1, 4.3] 

2222 >>> y = [3, 1.1, 0.12] 

2223 >>> X = np.stack((x, y), axis=0) 

2224 >>> print(np.cov(X)) 

2225 [[ 11.71 -4.286 ] 

2226 [ -4.286 2.14413333]] 

2227 >>> print(np.cov(x, y)) 

2228 [[ 11.71 -4.286 ] 

2229 [ -4.286 2.14413333]] 

2230 >>> print(np.cov(x)) 

2231 11.71 

2232 

2233 """ 

2234 # Check inputs 

2235 if ddof is not None and ddof != int(ddof): 

2236 raise ValueError( 

2237 "ddof must be integer") 

2238 

2239 # Handles complex arrays too 

2240 m = np.asarray(m) 

2241 if m.ndim > 2: 

2242 raise ValueError("m has more than 2 dimensions") 

2243 

2244 if y is None: 

2245 dtype = np.result_type(m, np.float64) 

2246 else: 

2247 y = np.asarray(y) 

2248 if y.ndim > 2: 

2249 raise ValueError("y has more than 2 dimensions") 

2250 dtype = np.result_type(m, y, np.float64) 

2251 

2252 X = array(m, ndmin=2, dtype=dtype) 

2253 if not rowvar and X.shape[0] != 1: 

2254 X = X.T 

2255 if X.shape[0] == 0: 

2256 return np.array([]).reshape(0, 0) 

2257 if y is not None: 

2258 y = array(y, copy=False, ndmin=2, dtype=dtype) 

2259 if not rowvar and y.shape[0] != 1: 

2260 y = y.T 

2261 X = np.concatenate((X, y), axis=0) 

2262 

2263 if ddof is None: 

2264 if bias == 0: 

2265 ddof = 1 

2266 else: 

2267 ddof = 0 

2268 

2269 # Get the product of frequencies and weights 

2270 w = None 

2271 if fweights is not None: 

2272 fweights = np.asarray(fweights, dtype=float) 

2273 if not np.all(fweights == np.around(fweights)): 

2274 raise TypeError( 

2275 "fweights must be integer") 

2276 if fweights.ndim > 1: 

2277 raise RuntimeError( 

2278 "cannot handle multidimensional fweights") 

2279 if fweights.shape[0] != X.shape[1]: 

2280 raise RuntimeError( 

2281 "incompatible numbers of samples and fweights") 

2282 if any(fweights < 0): 

2283 raise ValueError( 

2284 "fweights cannot be negative") 

2285 w = fweights 

2286 if aweights is not None: 

2287 aweights = np.asarray(aweights, dtype=float) 

2288 if aweights.ndim > 1: 

2289 raise RuntimeError( 

2290 "cannot handle multidimensional aweights") 

2291 if aweights.shape[0] != X.shape[1]: 

2292 raise RuntimeError( 

2293 "incompatible numbers of samples and aweights") 

2294 if any(aweights < 0): 

2295 raise ValueError( 

2296 "aweights cannot be negative") 

2297 if w is None: 

2298 w = aweights 

2299 else: 

2300 w *= aweights 

2301 

2302 avg, w_sum = average(X, axis=1, weights=w, returned=True) 

2303 w_sum = w_sum[0] 

2304 

2305 # Determine the normalization 

2306 if w is None: 

2307 fact = X.shape[1] - ddof 

2308 elif ddof == 0: 

2309 fact = w_sum 

2310 elif aweights is None: 

2311 fact = w_sum - ddof 

2312 else: 

2313 fact = w_sum - ddof*sum(w*aweights)/w_sum 

2314 

2315 if fact <= 0: 

2316 warnings.warn("Degrees of freedom <= 0 for slice", 

2317 RuntimeWarning, stacklevel=2) 

2318 fact = 0.0 

2319 

2320 X -= avg[:, None] 

2321 if w is None: 

2322 X_T = X.T 

2323 else: 

2324 X_T = (X*w).T 

2325 c = dot(X, X_T.conj()) 

2326 c *= np.true_divide(1, fact) 

2327 return c.squeeze() 

2328 

2329 

2330def corrcoef(x, y=None, rowvar=True, bias=np._NoValue, ddof=np._NoValue): 

2331 """ 

2332 Return Pearson product-moment correlation coefficients. 

2333 

2334 Please refer to the documentation for `cov` for more detail. The 

2335 relationship between the correlation coefficient matrix, `R`, and the 

2336 covariance matrix, `C`, is 

2337 

2338 .. math:: R_{ij} = \\frac{ C_{ij} } { \\sqrt{ C_{ii} * C_{jj} } } 

2339 

2340 The values of `R` are between -1 and 1, inclusive. 

2341 

2342 Parameters 

2343 ---------- 

2344 x : array_like 

2345 A 1-D or 2-D array containing multiple variables and observations. 

2346 Each row of `x` represents a variable, and each column a single 

2347 observation of all those variables. Also see `rowvar` below. 

2348 y : array_like, optional 

2349 An additional set of variables and observations. `y` has the same 

2350 shape as `x`. 

2351 rowvar : bool, optional 

2352 If `rowvar` is True (default), then each row represents a 

2353 variable, with observations in the columns. Otherwise, the relationship 

2354 is transposed: each column represents a variable, while the rows 

2355 contain observations. 

2356 bias : _NoValue, optional 

2357 Has no effect, do not use. 

2358 

2359 .. deprecated:: 1.10.0 

2360 ddof : _NoValue, optional 

2361 Has no effect, do not use. 

2362 

2363 .. deprecated:: 1.10.0 

2364 

2365 Returns 

2366 ------- 

2367 R : ndarray 

2368 The correlation coefficient matrix of the variables. 

2369 

2370 See Also 

2371 -------- 

2372 cov : Covariance matrix 

2373 

2374 Notes 

2375 ----- 

2376 Due to floating point rounding the resulting array may not be Hermitian, 

2377 the diagonal elements may not be 1, and the elements may not satisfy the 

2378 inequality abs(a) <= 1. The real and imaginary parts are clipped to the 

2379 interval [-1, 1] in an attempt to improve on that situation but is not 

2380 much help in the complex case. 

2381 

2382 This function accepts but discards arguments `bias` and `ddof`. This is 

2383 for backwards compatibility with previous versions of this function. These 

2384 arguments had no effect on the return values of the function and can be 

2385 safely ignored in this and previous versions of numpy. 

2386 

2387 """ 

2388 if bias is not np._NoValue or ddof is not np._NoValue: 

2389 # 2015-03-15, 1.10 

2390 warnings.warn('bias and ddof have no effect and are deprecated', 

2391 DeprecationWarning, stacklevel=2) 

2392 c = cov(x, y, rowvar) 

2393 try: 

2394 d = diag(c) 

2395 except ValueError: 

2396 # scalar covariance 

2397 # nan if incorrect value (nan, inf, 0), 1 otherwise 

2398 return c / c 

2399 stddev = sqrt(d.real) 

2400 c /= stddev[:, None] 

2401 c /= stddev[None, :] 

2402 

2403 # Clip real and imaginary parts to [-1, 1]. This does not guarantee 

2404 # abs(a[i,j]) <= 1 for complex arrays, but is the best we can do without 

2405 # excessive work. 

2406 np.clip(c.real, -1, 1, out=c.real) 

2407 if np.iscomplexobj(c): 

2408 np.clip(c.imag, -1, 1, out=c.imag) 

2409 

2410 return c 

2411 

2412 

2413def blackman(M): 

2414 """ 

2415 Return the Blackman window. 

2416 

2417 The Blackman window is a taper formed by using the first three 

2418 terms of a summation of cosines. It was designed to have close to the 

2419 minimal leakage possible. It is close to optimal, only slightly worse 

2420 than a Kaiser window. 

2421 

2422 Parameters 

2423 ---------- 

2424 M : int 

2425 Number of points in the output window. If zero or less, an empty 

2426 array is returned. 

2427 

2428 Returns 

2429 ------- 

2430 out : ndarray 

2431 The window, with the maximum value normalized to one (the value one 

2432 appears only if the number of samples is odd). 

2433 

2434 See Also 

2435 -------- 

2436 bartlett, hamming, hanning, kaiser 

2437 

2438 Notes 

2439 ----- 

2440 The Blackman window is defined as 

2441 

2442 .. math:: w(n) = 0.42 - 0.5 \\cos(2\\pi n/M) + 0.08 \\cos(4\\pi n/M) 

2443 

2444 Most references to the Blackman window come from the signal processing 

2445 literature, where it is used as one of many windowing functions for 

2446 smoothing values. It is also known as an apodization (which means 

2447 "removing the foot", i.e. smoothing discontinuities at the beginning 

2448 and end of the sampled signal) or tapering function. It is known as a 

2449 "near optimal" tapering function, almost as good (by some measures) 

2450 as the kaiser window. 

2451 

2452 References 

2453 ---------- 

2454 Blackman, R.B. and Tukey, J.W., (1958) The measurement of power spectra, 

2455 Dover Publications, New York. 

2456 

2457 Oppenheim, A.V., and R.W. Schafer. Discrete-Time Signal Processing. 

2458 Upper Saddle River, NJ: Prentice-Hall, 1999, pp. 468-471. 

2459 

2460 Examples 

2461 -------- 

2462 >>> np.blackman(12) 

2463 array([ -1.38777878e-17, 3.26064346e-02, 1.59903635e-01, 

2464 4.14397981e-01, 7.36045180e-01, 9.67046769e-01, 

2465 9.67046769e-01, 7.36045180e-01, 4.14397981e-01, 

2466 1.59903635e-01, 3.26064346e-02, -1.38777878e-17]) 

2467 

2468 

2469 Plot the window and the frequency response: 

2470 

2471 >>> from numpy.fft import fft, fftshift 

2472 >>> window = np.blackman(51) 

2473 >>> plt.plot(window) 

2474 [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x...>] 

2475 >>> plt.title("Blackman window") 

2476 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2477 >>> plt.ylabel("Amplitude") 

2478 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2479 >>> plt.xlabel("Sample") 

2480 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2481 >>> plt.show() 

2482 

2483 >>> plt.figure() 

2484 <matplotlib.figure.Figure object at 0x...> 

2485 >>> A = fft(window, 2048) / 25.5 

2486 >>> mag = np.abs(fftshift(A)) 

2487 >>> freq = np.linspace(-0.5, 0.5, len(A)) 

2488 >>> response = 20 * np.log10(mag) 

2489 >>> response = np.clip(response, -100, 100) 

2490 >>> plt.plot(freq, response) 

2491 [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x...>] 

2492 >>> plt.title("Frequency response of Blackman window") 

2493 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2494 >>> plt.ylabel("Magnitude [dB]") 

2495 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2496 >>> plt.xlabel("Normalized frequency [cycles per sample]") 

2497 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2498 >>> plt.axis('tight') 

2499 (-0.5, 0.5, -100.0, ...) 

2500 >>> plt.show() 

2501 

2502 """ 

2503 if M < 1: 

2504 return array([]) 

2505 if M == 1: 

2506 return ones(1, float) 

2507 n = arange(0, M) 

2508 return 0.42 - 0.5*cos(2.0*pi*n/(M-1)) + 0.08*cos(4.0*pi*n/(M-1)) 

2509 

2510 

2511def bartlett(M): 

2512 """ 

2513 Return the Bartlett window. 

2514 

2515 The Bartlett window is very similar to a triangular window, except 

2516 that the end points are at zero. It is often used in signal 

2517 processing for tapering a signal, without generating too much 

2518 ripple in the frequency domain. 

2519 

2520 Parameters 

2521 ---------- 

2522 M : int 

2523 Number of points in the output window. If zero or less, an 

2524 empty array is returned. 

2525 

2526 Returns 

2527 ------- 

2528 out : array 

2529 The triangular window, with the maximum value normalized to one 

2530 (the value one appears only if the number of samples is odd), with 

2531 the first and last samples equal to zero. 

2532 

2533 See Also 

2534 -------- 

2535 blackman, hamming, hanning, kaiser 

2536 

2537 Notes 

2538 ----- 

2539 The Bartlett window is defined as 

2540 

2541 .. math:: w(n) = \\frac{2}{M-1} \\left( 

2542 \\frac{M-1}{2} - \\left|n - \\frac{M-1}{2}\\right| 

2543 \\right) 

2544 

2545 Most references to the Bartlett window come from the signal 

2546 processing literature, where it is used as one of many windowing 

2547 functions for smoothing values. Note that convolution with this 

2548 window produces linear interpolation. It is also known as an 

2549 apodization (which means"removing the foot", i.e. smoothing 

2550 discontinuities at the beginning and end of the sampled signal) or 

2551 tapering function. The fourier transform of the Bartlett is the product 

2552 of two sinc functions. 

2553 Note the excellent discussion in Kanasewich. 

2554 

2555 References 

2556 ---------- 

2557 .. [1] M.S. Bartlett, "Periodogram Analysis and Continuous Spectra", 

2558 Biometrika 37, 1-16, 1950. 

2559 .. [2] E.R. Kanasewich, "Time Sequence Analysis in Geophysics", 

2560 The University of Alberta Press, 1975, pp. 109-110. 

2561 .. [3] A.V. Oppenheim and R.W. Schafer, "Discrete-Time Signal 

2562 Processing", Prentice-Hall, 1999, pp. 468-471. 

2563 .. [4] Wikipedia, "Window function", 

2564 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Window_function 

2565 .. [5] W.H. Press, B.P. Flannery, S.A. Teukolsky, and W.T. Vetterling, 

2566 "Numerical Recipes", Cambridge University Press, 1986, page 429. 

2567 

2568 Examples 

2569 -------- 

2570 >>> np.bartlett(12) 

2571 array([ 0. , 0.18181818, 0.36363636, 0.54545455, 0.72727273, 

2572 0.90909091, 0.90909091, 0.72727273, 0.54545455, 0.36363636, 

2573 0.18181818, 0. ]) 

2574 

2575 Plot the window and its frequency response (requires SciPy and matplotlib): 

2576 

2577 >>> from numpy.fft import fft, fftshift 

2578 >>> window = np.bartlett(51) 

2579 >>> plt.plot(window) 

2580 [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x...>] 

2581 >>> plt.title("Bartlett window") 

2582 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2583 >>> plt.ylabel("Amplitude") 

2584 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2585 >>> plt.xlabel("Sample") 

2586 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2587 >>> plt.show() 

2588 

2589 >>> plt.figure() 

2590 <matplotlib.figure.Figure object at 0x...> 

2591 >>> A = fft(window, 2048) / 25.5 

2592 >>> mag = np.abs(fftshift(A)) 

2593 >>> freq = np.linspace(-0.5, 0.5, len(A)) 

2594 >>> response = 20 * np.log10(mag) 

2595 >>> response = np.clip(response, -100, 100) 

2596 >>> plt.plot(freq, response) 

2597 [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x...>] 

2598 >>> plt.title("Frequency response of Bartlett window") 

2599 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2600 >>> plt.ylabel("Magnitude [dB]") 

2601 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2602 >>> plt.xlabel("Normalized frequency [cycles per sample]") 

2603 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2604 >>> plt.axis('tight') 

2605 (-0.5, 0.5, -100.0, ...) 

2606 >>> plt.show() 

2607 

2608 """ 

2609 if M < 1: 

2610 return array([]) 

2611 if M == 1: 

2612 return ones(1, float) 

2613 n = arange(0, M) 

2614 return where(less_equal(n, (M-1)/2.0), 2.0*n/(M-1), 2.0 - 2.0*n/(M-1)) 

2615 

2616 

2617def hanning(M): 

2618 """ 

2619 Return the Hanning window. 

2620 

2621 The Hanning window is a taper formed by using a weighted cosine. 

2622 

2623 Parameters 

2624 ---------- 

2625 M : int 

2626 Number of points in the output window. If zero or less, an 

2627 empty array is returned. 

2628 

2629 Returns 

2630 ------- 

2631 out : ndarray, shape(M,) 

2632 The window, with the maximum value normalized to one (the value 

2633 one appears only if `M` is odd). 

2634 

2635 See Also 

2636 -------- 

2637 bartlett, blackman, hamming, kaiser 

2638 

2639 Notes 

2640 ----- 

2641 The Hanning window is defined as 

2642 

2643 .. math:: w(n) = 0.5 - 0.5cos\\left(\\frac{2\\pi{n}}{M-1}\\right) 

2644 \\qquad 0 \\leq n \\leq M-1 

2645 

2646 The Hanning was named for Julius von Hann, an Austrian meteorologist. 

2647 It is also known as the Cosine Bell. Some authors prefer that it be 

2648 called a Hann window, to help avoid confusion with the very similar 

2649 Hamming window. 

2650 

2651 Most references to the Hanning window come from the signal processing 

2652 literature, where it is used as one of many windowing functions for 

2653 smoothing values. It is also known as an apodization (which means 

2654 "removing the foot", i.e. smoothing discontinuities at the beginning 

2655 and end of the sampled signal) or tapering function. 

2656 

2657 References 

2658 ---------- 

2659 .. [1] Blackman, R.B. and Tukey, J.W., (1958) The measurement of power 

2660 spectra, Dover Publications, New York. 

2661 .. [2] E.R. Kanasewich, "Time Sequence Analysis in Geophysics", 

2662 The University of Alberta Press, 1975, pp. 106-108. 

2663 .. [3] Wikipedia, "Window function", 

2664 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Window_function 

2665 .. [4] W.H. Press, B.P. Flannery, S.A. Teukolsky, and W.T. Vetterling, 

2666 "Numerical Recipes", Cambridge University Press, 1986, page 425. 

2667 

2668 Examples 

2669 -------- 

2670 >>> np.hanning(12) 

2671 array([ 0. , 0.07937323, 0.29229249, 0.57115742, 0.82743037, 

2672 0.97974649, 0.97974649, 0.82743037, 0.57115742, 0.29229249, 

2673 0.07937323, 0. ]) 

2674 

2675 Plot the window and its frequency response: 

2676 

2677 >>> from numpy.fft import fft, fftshift 

2678 >>> window = np.hanning(51) 

2679 >>> plt.plot(window) 

2680 [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x...>] 

2681 >>> plt.title("Hann window") 

2682 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2683 >>> plt.ylabel("Amplitude") 

2684 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2685 >>> plt.xlabel("Sample") 

2686 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2687 >>> plt.show() 

2688 

2689 >>> plt.figure() 

2690 <matplotlib.figure.Figure object at 0x...> 

2691 >>> A = fft(window, 2048) / 25.5 

2692 >>> mag = np.abs(fftshift(A)) 

2693 >>> freq = np.linspace(-0.5, 0.5, len(A)) 

2694 >>> response = 20 * np.log10(mag) 

2695 >>> response = np.clip(response, -100, 100) 

2696 >>> plt.plot(freq, response) 

2697 [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x...>] 

2698 >>> plt.title("Frequency response of the Hann window") 

2699 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2700 >>> plt.ylabel("Magnitude [dB]") 

2701 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2702 >>> plt.xlabel("Normalized frequency [cycles per sample]") 

2703 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2704 >>> plt.axis('tight') 

2705 (-0.5, 0.5, -100.0, ...) 

2706 >>> plt.show() 

2707 

2708 """ 

2709 if M < 1: 

2710 return array([]) 

2711 if M == 1: 

2712 return ones(1, float) 

2713 n = arange(0, M) 

2714 return 0.5 - 0.5*cos(2.0*pi*n/(M-1))

2717def hamming(M): 

2718 """ 

2719 Return the Hamming window. 

2720 

2721 The Hamming window is a taper formed by using a weighted cosine. 

2722 

2723 Parameters 

2724 ---------- 

2725 M : int 

2726 Number of points in the output window. If zero or less, an 

2727 empty array is returned. 

2728 

2729 Returns 

2730 ------- 

2731 out : ndarray 

2732 The window, with the maximum value normalized to one (the value 

2733 one appears only if the number of samples is odd). 

2734 

2735 See Also 

2736 -------- 

2737 bartlett, blackman, hanning, kaiser 

2738 

2739 Notes 

2740 ----- 

2741 The Hamming window is defined as 

2742 

2743 .. math:: w(n) = 0.54 - 0.46cos\\left(\\frac{2\\pi{n}}{M-1}\\right) 

2744 \\qquad 0 \\leq n \\leq M-1 

2745 

2746 The Hamming was named for R. W. Hamming, an associate of J. W. Tukey 

2747 and is described in Blackman and Tukey. It was recommended for 

2748 smoothing the truncated autocovariance function in the time domain. 

2749 Most references to the Hamming window come from the signal processing 

2750 literature, where it is used as one of many windowing functions for 

2751 smoothing values. It is also known as an apodization (which means 

2752 "removing the foot", i.e. smoothing discontinuities at the beginning 

2753 and end of the sampled signal) or tapering function. 

2754 

2755 References 

2756 ---------- 

2757 .. [1] Blackman, R.B. and Tukey, J.W., (1958) The measurement of power 

2758 spectra, Dover Publications, New York. 

2759 .. [2] E.R. Kanasewich, "Time Sequence Analysis in Geophysics", The 

2760 University of Alberta Press, 1975, pp. 109-110. 

2761 .. [3] Wikipedia, "Window function", 

2762 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Window_function 

2763 .. [4] W.H. Press, B.P. Flannery, S.A. Teukolsky, and W.T. Vetterling, 

2764 "Numerical Recipes", Cambridge University Press, 1986, page 425. 

2765 

2766 Examples 

2767 -------- 

2768 >>> np.hamming(12) 

2769 array([ 0.08 , 0.15302337, 0.34890909, 0.60546483, 0.84123594, 

2770 0.98136677, 0.98136677, 0.84123594, 0.60546483, 0.34890909, 

2771 0.15302337, 0.08 ]) 

2772 

2773 Plot the window and the frequency response: 

2774 

2775 >>> from numpy.fft import fft, fftshift 

2776 >>> window = np.hamming(51) 

2777 >>> plt.plot(window) 

2778 [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x...>] 

2779 >>> plt.title("Hamming window") 

2780 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2781 >>> plt.ylabel("Amplitude") 

2782 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2783 >>> plt.xlabel("Sample") 

2784 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2785 >>> plt.show() 

2786 

2787 >>> plt.figure() 

2788 <matplotlib.figure.Figure object at 0x...> 

2789 >>> A = fft(window, 2048) / 25.5 

2790 >>> mag = np.abs(fftshift(A)) 

2791 >>> freq = np.linspace(-0.5, 0.5, len(A)) 

2792 >>> response = 20 * np.log10(mag) 

2793 >>> response = np.clip(response, -100, 100) 

2794 >>> plt.plot(freq, response) 

2795 [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x...>] 

2796 >>> plt.title("Frequency response of Hamming window") 

2797 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2798 >>> plt.ylabel("Magnitude [dB]") 

2799 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2800 >>> plt.xlabel("Normalized frequency [cycles per sample]") 

2801 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

2802 >>> plt.axis('tight') 

2803 (-0.5, 0.5, -100.0, ...) 

2804 >>> plt.show() 

2805 

2806 """ 

2807 if M < 1: 

2808 return array([]) 

2809 if M == 1: 

2810 return ones(1, float) 

2811 n = arange(0, M) 

2812 return 0.54 - 0.46*cos(2.0*pi*n/(M-1))

2877 

2878def _chbevl(x, vals): 

2879 b0 = vals[0] 

2880 b1 = 0.0 

2881 

2882 for i in range(1, len(vals)): 

2883 b2 = b1 

2884 b1 = b0 

2885 b0 = x*b1 - b2 + vals[i] 

2886 

2887 return 0.5*(b0 - b2) 

2888 

2889 

2890def _i0_1(x): 

2891 return exp(x) * _chbevl(x/2.0-2, _i0A) 

2892 

2893 

2894def _i0_2(x): 

2895 return exp(x) * _chbevl(32.0/x - 2.0, _i0B) / sqrt(x) 

2896 

2897 

2898def i0(x): 

2899 """ 

2900 Modified Bessel function of the first kind, order 0. 

2901 

2902 Usually denoted :math:`I_0`. This function does broadcast, but will *not* 

2903 "up-cast" int dtype arguments unless accompanied by at least one float or 

2904 complex dtype argument (see Raises below). 

2905 

2906 Parameters 

2907 ---------- 

2908 x : array_like, dtype float or complex 

2909 Argument of the Bessel function. 

2910 

2911 Returns 

2912 ------- 

2913 out : ndarray, shape = x.shape, dtype = x.dtype 

2914 The modified Bessel function evaluated at each of the elements of `x`. 

2915 

2916 Raises 

2917 ------ 

2918 TypeError: array cannot be safely cast to required type 

2919 If argument consists exclusively of int dtypes. 

2920 

2921 See Also 

2922 -------- 

2923 scipy.special.iv, scipy.special.ive 

2924 

2925 Notes 

2926 ----- 

2927 We use the algorithm published by Clenshaw [1]_ and referenced by 

2928 Abramowitz and Stegun [2]_, for which the function domain is 

2929 partitioned into the two intervals [0,8] and (8,inf), and Chebyshev 

2930 polynomial expansions are employed in each interval. Relative error on 

2931 the domain [0,30] using IEEE arithmetic is documented [3]_ as having a 

2932 peak of 5.8e-16 with an rms of 1.4e-16 (n = 30000). 

2933 

2934 References 

2935 ---------- 

2936 .. [1] C. W. Clenshaw, "Chebyshev series for mathematical functions", in 

2937 *National Physical Laboratory Mathematical Tables*, vol. 5, London: 

2938 Her Majesty's Stationery Office, 1962. 

2939 .. [2] M. Abramowitz and I. A. Stegun, *Handbook of Mathematical 

2940 Functions*, 10th printing, New York: Dover, 1964, pp. 379. 

2941 http://www.math.sfu.ca/~cbm/aands/page_379.htm 

2942 .. [3] http://kobesearch.cpan.org/htdocs/Math-Cephes/Math/Cephes.html 

2943 

2944 Examples 

2945 -------- 

2946 >>> np.i0([0.]) 

2947 array(1.0) 

2948 >>> np.i0([0., 1. + 2j]) 

2949 array([ 1.00000000+0.j , 0.18785373+0.64616944j]) 

2950 

2951 """ 

2952 x = atleast_1d(x).copy() 

2953 y = empty_like(x) 

2954 ind = (x < 0) 

2955 x[ind] = -x[ind] 

2956 ind = (x <= 8.0) 

2957 y[ind] = _i0_1(x[ind]) 

2958 ind2 = ~ind 

2959 y[ind2] = _i0_2(x[ind2]) 

2960 return y.squeeze() 

2961 

2962## End of cephes code for i0 

2963 

2964 

2965def kaiser(M, beta): 

2966 """ 

2967 Return the Kaiser window. 

2968 

2969 The Kaiser window is a taper formed by using a Bessel function. 

2970 

2971 Parameters 

2972 ---------- 

2973 M : int 

2974 Number of points in the output window. If zero or less, an 

2975 empty array is returned. 

2976 beta : float 

2977 Shape parameter for window. 

2978 

2979 Returns 

2980 ------- 

2981 out : array 

2982 The window, with the maximum value normalized to one (the value 

2983 one appears only if the number of samples is odd). 

2984 

2985 See Also 

2986 -------- 

2987 bartlett, blackman, hamming, hanning 

2988 

2989 Notes 

2990 ----- 

2991 The Kaiser window is defined as 

2992 

2993 .. math:: w(n) = I_0\\left( \\beta \\sqrt{1-\\frac{4n^2}{(M-1)^2}} 

2994 \\right)/I_0(\\beta) 

2995 

2996 with 

2997 

2998 .. math:: \\quad -\\frac{M-1}{2} \\leq n \\leq \\frac{M-1}{2}, 

2999 

3000 where :math:`I_0` is the modified zeroth-order Bessel function. 

3001 

3002 The Kaiser was named for Jim Kaiser, who discovered a simple 

3003 approximation to the DPSS window based on Bessel functions. The Kaiser 

3004 window is a very good approximation to the Digital Prolate Spheroidal 

3005 Sequence, or Slepian window, which is the transform which maximizes the 

3006 energy in the main lobe of the window relative to total energy. 

3007 

3008 The Kaiser can approximate many other windows by varying the beta 

3009 parameter. 

3010 

3011 ==== ======================= 

3012 beta Window shape 

3013 ==== ======================= 

3014 0 Rectangular 

3015 5 Similar to a Hamming 

3016 6 Similar to a Hanning 

3017 8.6 Similar to a Blackman 

3018 ==== ======================= 

3019 

3020 A beta value of 14 is probably a good starting point. Note that as beta 

3021 gets large, the window narrows, and so the number of samples needs to be 

3022 large enough to sample the increasingly narrow spike, otherwise NaNs will 

3023 get returned. 

3024 

3025 Most references to the Kaiser window come from the signal processing 

3026 literature, where it is used as one of many windowing functions for 

3027 smoothing values. It is also known as an apodization (which means 

3028 "removing the foot", i.e. smoothing discontinuities at the beginning 

3029 and end of the sampled signal) or tapering function. 

3030 

3031 References 

3032 ---------- 

3033 .. [1] J. F. Kaiser, "Digital Filters" - Ch 7 in "Systems analysis by 

3034 digital computer", Editors: F.F. Kuo and J.F. Kaiser, p 218-285. 

3035 John Wiley and Sons, New York, (1966). 

3036 .. [2] E.R. Kanasewich, "Time Sequence Analysis in Geophysics", The 

3037 University of Alberta Press, 1975, pp. 177-178. 

3038 .. [3] Wikipedia, "Window function", 

3039 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Window_function 

3040 

3041 Examples 

3042 -------- 

3043 >>> np.kaiser(12, 14) 

3044 array([ 7.72686684e-06, 3.46009194e-03, 4.65200189e-02, 

3045 2.29737120e-01, 5.99885316e-01, 9.45674898e-01, 

3046 9.45674898e-01, 5.99885316e-01, 2.29737120e-01, 

3047 4.65200189e-02, 3.46009194e-03, 7.72686684e-06]) 

3048 

3049 

3050 Plot the window and the frequency response: 

3051 

3052 >>> from numpy.fft import fft, fftshift 

3053 >>> window = np.kaiser(51, 14) 

3054 >>> plt.plot(window) 

3055 [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x...>] 

3056 >>> plt.title("Kaiser window") 

3057 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

3058 >>> plt.ylabel("Amplitude") 

3059 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

3060 >>> plt.xlabel("Sample") 

3061 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

3062 >>> plt.show() 

3063 

3064 >>> plt.figure() 

3065 <matplotlib.figure.Figure object at 0x...> 

3066 >>> A = fft(window, 2048) / 25.5 

3067 >>> mag = np.abs(fftshift(A)) 

3068 >>> freq = np.linspace(-0.5, 0.5, len(A)) 

3069 >>> response = 20 * np.log10(mag) 

3070 >>> response = np.clip(response, -100, 100) 

3071 >>> plt.plot(freq, response) 

3072 [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x...>] 

3073 >>> plt.title("Frequency response of Kaiser window") 

3074 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

3075 >>> plt.ylabel("Magnitude [dB]") 

3076 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

3077 >>> plt.xlabel("Normalized frequency [cycles per sample]") 

3078 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

3079 >>> plt.axis('tight') 

3080 (-0.5, 0.5, -100.0, ...) 

3081 >>> plt.show() 

3082 

3083 """ 

3084 from numpy.dual import i0 

3085 if M == 1: 

3086 return np.array([1.]) 

3087 n = arange(0, M) 

3088 alpha = (M-1)/2.0 

3089 return i0(beta * sqrt(1-((n-alpha)/alpha)**2.0))/i0(float(beta)) 

3090 

3091 

3092def sinc(x): 

3093 """ 

3094 Return the sinc function. 

3095 

3096 The sinc function is :math:`\\sin(\\pi x)/(\\pi x)`. 

3097 

3098 Parameters 

3099 ---------- 

3100 x : ndarray 

3101 Array (possibly multi-dimensional) of values for which to to 

3102 calculate ``sinc(x)``. 

3103 

3104 Returns 

3105 ------- 

3106 out : ndarray 

3107 ``sinc(x)``, which has the same shape as the input. 

3108 

3109 Notes 

3110 ----- 

3111 ``sinc(0)`` is the limit value 1. 

3112 

3113 The name sinc is short for "sine cardinal" or "sinus cardinalis". 

3114 

3115 The sinc function is used in various signal processing applications, 

3116 including in anti-aliasing, in the construction of a Lanczos resampling 

3117 filter, and in interpolation. 

3118 

3119 For bandlimited interpolation of discrete-time signals, the ideal 

3120 interpolation kernel is proportional to the sinc function. 

3121 

3122 References 

3123 ---------- 

3124 .. [1] Weisstein, Eric W. "Sinc Function." From MathWorld--A Wolfram Web 

3125 Resource. http://mathworld.wolfram.com/SincFunction.html 

3126 .. [2] Wikipedia, "Sinc function", 

3127 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinc_function 

3128 

3129 Examples 

3130 -------- 

3131 >>> x = np.linspace(-4, 4, 41) 

3132 >>> np.sinc(x) 

3133 array([ -3.89804309e-17, -4.92362781e-02, -8.40918587e-02, 

3134 -8.90384387e-02, -5.84680802e-02, 3.89804309e-17, 

3135 6.68206631e-02, 1.16434881e-01, 1.26137788e-01, 

3136 8.50444803e-02, -3.89804309e-17, -1.03943254e-01, 

3137 -1.89206682e-01, -2.16236208e-01, -1.55914881e-01, 

3138 3.89804309e-17, 2.33872321e-01, 5.04551152e-01, 

3139 7.56826729e-01, 9.35489284e-01, 1.00000000e+00, 

3140 9.35489284e-01, 7.56826729e-01, 5.04551152e-01, 

3141 2.33872321e-01, 3.89804309e-17, -1.55914881e-01, 

3142 -2.16236208e-01, -1.89206682e-01, -1.03943254e-01, 

3143 -3.89804309e-17, 8.50444803e-02, 1.26137788e-01, 

3144 1.16434881e-01, 6.68206631e-02, 3.89804309e-17, 

3145 -5.84680802e-02, -8.90384387e-02, -8.40918587e-02, 

3146 -4.92362781e-02, -3.89804309e-17]) 

3147 

3148 >>> plt.plot(x, np.sinc(x)) 

3149 [<matplotlib.lines.Line2D object at 0x...>] 

3150 >>> plt.title("Sinc Function") 

3151 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

3152 >>> plt.ylabel("Amplitude") 

3153 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

3154 >>> plt.xlabel("X") 

3155 <matplotlib.text.Text object at 0x...> 

3156 >>> plt.show() 

3157 

3158 It works in 2-D as well: 

3159 

3160 >>> x = np.linspace(-4, 4, 401) 

3161 >>> xx = np.outer(x, x) 

3162 >>> plt.imshow(np.sinc(xx)) 

3163 <matplotlib.image.AxesImage object at 0x...> 

3164 

3165 """ 

3166 x = np.asanyarray(x) 

3167 y = pi * where(x == 0, 1.0e-20, x) 

3168 return sin(y)/y

3171def msort(a): 

3172 """ 

3173 Return a copy of an array sorted along the first axis. 

3174 

3175 Parameters 

3176 ---------- 

3177 a : array_like 

3178 Array to be sorted. 

3179 

3180 Returns 

3181 ------- 

3182 sorted_array : ndarray 

3183 Array of the same type and shape as `a`. 

3184 

3185 See Also 

3186 -------- 

3187 sort 

3188 

3189 Notes 

3190 ----- 

3191 ``np.msort(a)`` is equivalent to ``np.sort(a, axis=0)``. 

3192 

3193 """ 

3194 b = array(a, subok=True, copy=True) 

3195 b.sort(0) 

3196 return b
